entry.title: Why you should visit Greece's 'city of gastronomy'
entry.summary:
Thessaloniki's Ano Poli neighbourhood comes alive for lunch time thanks to traditional ouzerias like Tsinari. For two millennia, UNESCO City of Gastronomy Thessaloniki has been celebrated for its food culture, with flavours imported from across Europe, Africa and the Middle East.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The sun has just popped over Thessalonikiâ€™s jumbled rooftops but thereâ€™s already a queue out the door at Bougatsa Bantis. Inside, baker Philippos Bantis is handling the morning rush, bantering with his customers, many of whom he greets by name. It doesnâ€™t take long to get through the orders, since theyâ€™re all for the same thing: bougatsa, the rich, crispy, buttery filo tart thatâ€™s a breakfast staple in Thessaloniki. Traditionally, itâ€™sâ€¦

entry.title: This Thai prison is the best place to get a massage
Heard about The Ghan? Try Australia's other outback train instead
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Three hours: thatâ€™s how long it takes Shelita Buffet to get ready. There are false eyelashes to glue and cheekbones to contour; thereâ€™s a neon-bright wig to preen and a sequined pink leotard to tug on â€” and then thereâ€™s the generous application of glitter to beard. Looking this good takes time. The first honeyed rays of dawn have only just begun to wash into the mining town of Broken Hill and Shelita is standing on the station platform in a pair of blocky white heels, watching as I step off the train.
Iâ€™d boarded in Sydney the day before, leaving behind the skyscrapers and the Opera Houseâ€™s monumental clutch of alabaster shells to make tracks on a journey of continental proportions, rattling east to west across theâ€¦

entry.title: These birds are keeping a record of humanityâ€”one wrapper at a time
entry.summary:
Coots, rotund black waterbirds with big feet, donâ€™t seem like theyâ€™d run the waterways. But in Amsterdam, theyâ€™re the â€œcanal gangsters,â€ territorial and tenacious. They moved in from nearby farms more than thirty years ago, and theyâ€™ve toughed it out even in the dense urban core.
Scientists are researching how coots and other birds adapt to urban environments and whether that move is even a good thing.
Now, a new study unravels thirty years of plastic trash in one of the cityâ€™s biggest coot nests, revealing when coots build and breed in the city.
One particularly large nest documented 30 years of coots living in the red-light district. The oldest item in the nest was a Mars bar advertising the 1994 World Cup; the newest, a protein bar wrapper. Candy packaging, McDonaldâ€™s sanâ€¦

entry.title: How the Portuguese influenced Thailandâ€™s cuisine
entry.summary:
Bangkokâ€™s Kudi Chin neighborhood, in Thonburi on the western bank of the Chao Praya river, is a sleepy one; a jumble of narrow alleys and old houses, some on stilts. It is sometimes called Little Portugal, as it is home to a number of Thais descended from the Portuguese, who had settled here in the late 18th century.
The Portuguese were the first Western nation to contact the ancient Thai kingdom of Ayutthaya in 1511. They soon became a prominent trading partner, and introduced a number of fruits and vegetables, which are now staples in Thai cuisine. As Edward Van Roy writes in Siamese Melting Pot, tomatoes, chillies, peanuts, potatoes, and maize came to Thailand via Portugal. Some of the Thai names for vegetables reflect their imported origin; for example, potatoes are called man fâ€¦

entry.title: The rise and fall (and rise again?) of measles in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Measles cases continue to grow in the United States, which experts link to a rise in personal exemptions for school vaccine mandates. Measles requires 95 percent of a community to be immune to prevent the disease from spreading but the rise of exemptions in some communities has increased their risk of outbreaks.  The U.S. eliminated measles in 2000â€”but that hard-won achievement is now under threat. To contain the current outbreak, some states are following a new playbook to fight the infectious disease.
As the measles outbreak that began in West Texas continues to escalateâ€”with the number of U.S. cases this year now surpassing all those recorded in 2024â€”so does misinformation about how the disease spreads and how to prevent it.
Despite claims from Health and Human Seâ€¦

entry.title: How Hello Kitty helped post-WWII Japan conquer the world
entry.summary:
To much of the world, Hello Kitty is a charming cartoon iconâ€”a blank-faced cat with a red bow and an empire of lunch boxes, backpacks, and billion-dollar branding. But her global rise tells a far more complex story.
Born in 1974 amid Japanâ€™s efforts to recover from the devastation of World War II, Hello Kitty would become an unlikely agent of national reinvention. As the country confronted its imperialist past and sought to repair its international image, a quiet cultural revolution emergedâ€”rooted in the aesthetics of cuteness, or kawaii.
Through Hello Kitty, Japan began to reintroduce itself to the worldâ€”not as a former military power but as a rising expert in soft power.
At the end of World War II, Japan faced a reckoning. The countryâ€™s surrender in 1945 forced its politâ€¦

Since it launched in the early 2000s, GoPro has become synonymous with adventure sports videography. But GoPro cameras can be great tools for capturing unique perspectives on any trip, whether or not youâ€™re paddling Class VI white water or mountain biking downhill at night.Â
With more than 13 generations of cameras, plus tons of accessories, it may be difficult to know which GoPro camera is best for your journey. All GoPros offer not only professioâ€¦

entry.title: Why hikers should ditch the Alps for this mountain range
entry.summary:
Hikers should consider visiting the Carpathian Alps, which includes Romaniaâ€™s Transylvanian Alps, instead of the Swiss Alps. Itâ€™s not only a cost-effective option, but this mountain range has abundant wildlife, cultural sites, quaint villages, and the new Via Transilvanica hiking trail. The Transylvanian Alps provide visitors with abundant wildlife, UNESCO World Heritage sites, and quaint villagesâ€”without the crowds.
Why hikers should try this mountain range in RomaniaHikers pause on a ridgeline trail to look for the perfect selfie shot. Will their backdrop for the Instagram-worthy photo be the snow-dusted peaks or alpine meadows dotted with wild daisies and bellflowers? Meanwhile, below, traditional wooden churches poke through the morning mist; their spires rising above rustic viâ€¦

entry.title: Pakistan's mountains are callingâ€”here's why you should go
entry.summary:
The Karakoram range in Baltistan â€” even at 20,000ft, Laila Peak does not fall into the rangeâ€™s 100 tallest summits. Pakistanâ€™s far north holds some of the worldâ€™s highest peaks and has a proud cultural identity, but until now international visitors have been thin on the ground. A new hiking tour explores a spectacular corner of an often misunderstood country.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Friday prayers have ended, and the streets of Rawalpindi are hot, noisy and rammed. Mopeds growl as they edge through the crowd. In the throng, details catch the eye: henna-dyed beards and candy-striped hijabs; a knife-sharpener showering sparks over the pavement; four passengers and a goat in an auto-rickshaw. Down an alley, boys are playing cricket â€¦

entry.title: Centuries of history reduced to rubble after Myanmar earthquake
entry.summary: This building lies in rubble after a 7.7 magnitude earthquake struck Myanmar on March 28, 2025. Myanmar's Information Minister Maung Maung Ohn announced at a meeting in the capital that 4,589 people were injured and 221 others are missing as of  April 4, 2025. Myanmar's religious temples stood as symbols of faith and history. After the recent 7.7 magnitude earthquake, many are wondering: will they ever rise again or are they lost forever? A catastrophic earthquake shook Myanmarâ€™s northern region on March 28, collapsing historic and religious sites across the country. The 7.7 magnitude quake not only killed moreâ€¦

entry.title: The poison fruit from â€˜The White Lotusâ€™ is real
entry.summary:
Forbidden fruit has been a theme across all seasons of The White Lotus, HBOâ€™s series about a fictional high-end hotel chain. In season three, set in Thailand, the metaphor becomes literal when a hotel worker warns a guest not to eat the fruit of the pong pong tree, as it is toxic enough to kill.Â
Fans of the show are now chattering about whether that deadly narrative seed, planted in the season premiere, will bear fruit in the 90-minute finale as the character Timothy Ratliffâ€™s suicidal ideations continue to escalate.
(Inspired by White Lotus? Here are the Thai islands to visit.)
But what fans might not know is that the pong pong tree (Cerbera odollam) is a real poisonous plant that has been implicated in thousands of deaths a year in the past. The effects of its deadly fruiâ€¦

entry.title: Are tornadoes getting worse? Here's what we know
entry.summary:
Natural disasters like heat waves, fires, and floods are growing more dangerous because of climate change, but the effect a warming world has on tornadoes is complicated and inconclusive.
Thereâ€™s been a recorded increase in the overall number of observed tornadoes since 1950, according to National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration data, but experts say thatâ€™s largely a result of better technology such as Doppler radar. Thereâ€™s been no observed increase in the frequency of major tornadoes over time. Â
But given the pervasive influence of global warming on the atmosphere, it's unavoidable that climate change would impact tornadoes too, said Victor Gensini, an extreme weather expert at Northern Illinois University.
â€œInstead of asking: â€˜Did climate change cause this tornadoâ€¦

entry.title: What to know about tourist visas, and where you can go without one
entry.summary:
U.S. passport holders can travel to more than 120 countries without a visa, including Thailand. So, plan your stress-free trip that includes seeing Wat Chaiwatthanaram in Ayutthaya. U.S. passport holders can travel to more than 100 destinations without a tourist visa, but some popular vacation spots require them. We explain the different types of visas and how to apply.
Avid travelers are always dreaming about the next trip, whether itâ€™s an idyllic family vacation in the Caribbean, a romantic couples trip to Paris, or an immersive culinary tour in Japan. A stress-free journey is always in the forefront of every travelerâ€™s mind when planning a trip.Â Â If you own a U.S. passport, your ease of travel increases.Â Â Â
According toÂ the Passport Index, aÂ U.S. passportÂ currently ranks eiâ€¦

entry.title: Level up your birding with binoculars and spotting scopes
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Itâ€™s no wonder that birdwatching has quickly become a favorite pastime, with one 2022 survey finding three out of 10 Americans taking up the hobby. You donâ€™t need much to get started, other than a sturdy pair of shoes and perhaps a guidebook. However, if youâ€™re planning a wildlife watching tour or want to catch details such as the verdinâ€™s red-dabbed shoulders, you may want to invest in a good pair of binoculars and a spotting scope.Â
Lightweight aâ€¦

entry.title: Are we alone in the universe? These Mars rocks may tell us
entry.summary:
Across the Martian landscape, the view is breathtaking. Everything is quiet, except for a little robot patiently trundling up the sides of Jezero Crater. Perseverance, affectionately known as â€œPercy,â€ doesnâ€™t have the ability to appreciate the reddish-orange hues of the desert landscape like a human can. But the rover has been exploring the red planet since 2021, and itâ€™s been carefully amassing a rock collection that could change our understanding of Marsâ€™ history, how it compares to our own planet, and how we came to be here.
Mars wasnâ€™t always a desolate, dusty world. Scientists think that, at some point in the red planetâ€™s history, it was temperate much like Earth is today. But around three or four billion years ago, Marsâ€™s internal plumbing mysteriously shut offâ€”and as a result, â€¦

entry.title: Gaza: Paramedic still missing after aid worker killings, Palestinian Red Crescent Society calls for answers
entry.summary: The Palestinian Red Crescent Society (PRCS) on Friday called for urgent answers over the whereabouts of a missing paramedic, coupled with a full independent investigation into the killing of 15 humanitarian workers in Gaza on 23 March.

entry.title: World News in Brief: Cholera surges worldwide, DR Congo update, WHO leads global health emergency exercise
entry.summary: A global surge in cholera is threatening vulnerable people from Angola to Myanmar, fuelled by conflict, natural disasters and climate change, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Friday.

entry.title: UN rolls out key initiative to combat antisemitism
entry.summary: Amid rising concerns over antisemitism worldwide, the UN on Friday announced the roll out of a major action plan to combat the scourge â€“ aimed at enhancing monitoring and response across the whole UN system.

entry.summary: Amid reports of escalating settler violence in the West Bank, the UN rights office, OHCHR, briefed the Palestinian rights committee at UN Headquarters in New York, which also featured a screening of the Oscar winning documentary No Other Land.

entry.title: Sudan: Suffering continues amid massive destruction across Khartoum

entry.title: Appendix A: Demographic makeup of AI experts surveyed
entry.summary: The post Appendix A: Demographic makeup of AI experts surveyed appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix B: Selected tables by expert and public demographics
entry.summary: Note: We did not receive enough responses from Hispanic or Black experts to be able to report expert views by race and ethnicity; this reflects the racial and ethnic makeup of the field. These groupsâ€™ responses are incorporated into the general figures throughout. We also did not receive enough responses from experts working at nonprofits, [â€¦] The post Appendix B: Selected tables by expert and public demographics appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: This report is based on a pair of Pew Research Center surveys and a series of in-depth interviews. It draws on a nationally representative survey of U.S. adults who are members of the Centerâ€™s American Trends Panel (ATP), a survey of U.S.-based experts in artificial intelligence (AI) and 30 in-depth interviews with experts who participated [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Public and expert predictions for AIâ€™s next 20 years
entry.summary: We explore how the public and experts anticipate potential positive and negative impacts of AI across key areas of life and society in the coming decades. The post 3. Public and expert predictions for AIâ€™s next 20 years appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online atÂ pewresearch.org/internet. Primary researchers Colleen McClain, Senior ResearcherBrian Kennedy, Senior ResearcherJeffrey Gottfried, Associate Director, Internet and Technology ResearchÂ Monica Anderson, Director, Internet and Technology ResearchÂ Â Â Giancarlo Pasquini, Research AssociateÂ Research team Eileen Yam, Director, Science and Society ResearchAlec [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI
entry.summary: Experts and the public differ in their excitement and worries over AI's increased use, but both share concerns over regulation, misinformation and bias. The post 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI
entry.summary: Experts and the public differ in their excitement and worries over AI's increased use, but both share concerns over regulation, misinformation and bias. The post 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Artificial intelligence in daily life: Views and experiences
entry.summary: As AI becomes part of everyday life, we look at how the public and AI experts experience and view AI, including control of its role in their lives. The post 1. Artificial intelligence in daily life: Views and experiences appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How the U.S. Public and AI Experts View Artificial Intelligence
entry.summary: These groups are far apart in their enthusiasm and predictions for AI, but both want more personal control and worry about too little regulation. The post How the U.S. Public and AI Experts View Artificial Intelligence appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: â€˜Every piece tells a storyâ€™: Bombs to beauty, from Gaza to Ukraine
entry.summary: What happens to bombs after they land? Some explode. Some donâ€™t, leaving behind a deadly legacy of war, but now the remnants of conflict and devastation are being turned into wearable messages of peace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Armed violence displaces thousands as cholera outbreak worsens
entry.summary: Ongoing violence in North and South Kivu in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) continues to kill, injure and displace civilians, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) has warned.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Israeli military escalation in Syria, Nicaragua rights probe, South Sudan talks
entry.summary: The UN Special Envoy for Syria has condemned the repeated and intensifying military escalations by Israel in the country, including airstrikes that have caused civilian casualties.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights chief warns of increasing risk of atrocity crimes in Gaza
entry.summary: The recent killings of 15 medical personnel and humanitarian aid workers in Gaza raise further concerns over the commission of war crimes by the Israeli military, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights told the Security Council on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN envoy urges international support for West Africa and the Sahel
entry.summary: In a briefing to the Security Council on Thursday, the UN Special Representative for West Africa and the Sahel painted a mixed picture of the region, which is facing a growing terrorist threat but also political progress and encouraging initiatives.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar: UN chief calls for urgent access as quake toll mounts
entry.summary: The UN chief on Thursday called for immediate and unrestricted humanitarian access to Myanmar, where last weekâ€™s devastating earthquakes claimed over 3,000 lives and left millions in urgent need of aid.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: AIâ€™s $4.8 trillion future: UN warns of widening digital divide without urgent action
entry.summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is on course to become a $4.8 trillion global market by 2033 â€“ roughly the size of Germanyâ€™s economy â€“ but unless urgent action is taken, its benefits may remain in the hands of a privileged few, a new UN report warns.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan crisis: UN rights chief condemns extrajudicial killings in Khartoum
entry.summary: The fight for Sudanâ€™s capital, Khartoum, likely involved widespread summary executions of civilians following its recent recapture by the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF), UN human rights chief Volker TÃ¼rkÂ saidÂ on Thursday.

entry.title: Who invented sâ€™mores? Forget the mythsâ€”this is the real history
entry.summary:
Dorothy Christian Moore knew the rules when she climbed in the dark to the shipâ€™s bridge. â€œThis is strictly forbidden,â€ she wrote as she crossed the Atlantic Ocean, â€œand I hadnâ€™t been there two minutes before someone seized me roughly from behind.â€ She explained to the officer her pursuit of the sunrise, and together they watched the blue horizon split into silver, then blaze to goldâ€”like so many campfires that would define her years in the United States.
She arrived the next morning at the invitation of the Girl Scouts to spend the summer of 1923 sharing her skills. Her stint as a volunteer in an officerâ€™s hospital kitchen during World War I, feeding 150 men a day, had earned her the affectionate nickname â€œCookie.â€ After the war, she continued in public service as a leader in Girl Guâ€¦

entry.title: En todo el mundo, muchas personas abandonan las religiones de su infancia
entry.summary: Este comunicado de prensa se ha traducido del inglÃ©s original al espaÃ±ol. En muchos paÃ­ses del mundo, una quinta parte o mÃ¡s de todos los adultos ha abandonado el grupo religioso en el que se criaron. El cristianismo y el budismo han experimentado pÃ©rdidas especialmente grandes debido a este â€œcambio de religiÃ³nâ€, mientras que un [â€¦] The post En todo el mundo, muchas personas abandonan las religiones de su infancia appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How these two vitamin supplements could do more harm than good
entry.summary:
Fat-soluble vitamins, such as vitamin E photographed above, are stored in the body's fat reserves, which is why they have potential to accumulate to toxic levels. Fat-soluble vitamins are more likely to cause adverse effects if consumed in large doses. Hereâ€™s what the experts say about vitamin A and E.
Vitamins and supplements are a booming industry. And while there are many important supplements that benefit people with specific deficiencies or certain health conditions, research shows and experts agree that some synthetic vitamins could cause harms such as liver damage, hair loss, joint and muscle pain, and impaired vision.
"Everyone is always searching for that magic pill that will give them great health, but dietary supplements just aren't it because the benefits often donâ€¦

entry.title: The 'stork sisters' are saving one of India's largest and rarest birds
entry.summary:
Known locally asÂ hargila, the threatened Greater Adjutant stork has found a champion in an unlikely place: the Harglia Army,Â a group of about 20,000 rural women in India turned conservationists. Since 2014, the women have worked tirelessly to give the storks a desperately needed reputational revamp.Â
Once reviled as filthy, adjutants prey on fish, frogs, snakes, rats, and smaller birds like ducks, rummaging through landfills looking for carcasses (hargila translates to bone swallower). Its feeding habits cemented its reputation as unsanitary, a perception that led to a rapid population decline of the adjutant, one of the worldâ€™s largest and rarest storks. Native toÂ India's floodplains in Assam and Bihar, in 2023, it was recently listed as â€œnear threatenedâ€ by the International Union fâ€¦

entry.title: Penguins are insanely resilientâ€”and these explorers are revealing their secrets
entry.summary:
Borboroglu has been an Explorer since receiving the National Geographic/Buffett Award for Leadership in Conservation in 2018. Pablo â€œPopiâ€ GarcÃ­a Borboroglu and Bertie Gregory have been named the 2025 Rolex National Geographic Explorers of the Year.
As a boy growing up in Argentinaâ€™s Buenos Aires Province, Pablo â€œPopiâ€ GarcÃ­a Borboroglu was enchanted by his grandmotherâ€™s tales of her youthful visits to the teeming penguin colonies of Argentine Patagonia. He was a 19-year-old tour guide when he first glimpsed one, and it dawned on him then how important it was to share with others his sense of awe, inspiring them to protect penguins and their habitats.Â
A hemisphere away, Bertie Gregory came to a similar realization as a teenage wildlife photographer roaming the English countryâ€¦

entry.title: Why Florida's greatest family attractions are in the wild
entry.summary:
The observation towers in the Everglades National Park are perfect for taking in Florida's natural beauty. Americaâ€™s sunshine state is a natural playground, with wildlife sanctuaries and conservation-led attractions aimed at families.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Families know what to expect from a visit to Florida, right? Disney World, Universal Studios and other theme parks are the main reason for many visits to the southern state. Yet Florida has a lot more to offer kids on a stimulating, active and even educational family holiday. You can snorkel or try Snuba off the coast, kayak through mangrove channels inhabited by manatees, visit the holiday home of one of the worldâ€™s greatest inventors, explore the Everglades swamps, track dolphinâ€¦

entry.title: How the simple fork almost tore apart the fabric of society
entry.summary:
The dinner fork is one of the most common fixtures at tables worldwideâ€”so ordinary, so unthreatening, that few give it a second thought. But for centuries, the fork was condemned as a symbol of decadence, moral decay, and social arrogance.
Throughout most of history, fingers were natureâ€™s utensils. Knives sliced meat, spoons scooped broth, but only the hand completed the act of nourishment. The fork, however, was something else entirely. â€œThe introduction of the fork reflected and, at the same time, accelerated a series of profound changes in food culture and table habits,â€ says Lucia Galasso, a food anthropologist from Rome. It brought about a more controlled, refined eating processâ€”one that not everyone welcomed.
The forkâ€™s journey from forbidden instrument to universal utensilâ€¦

entry.title: These sea lions aren't 'demonic'â€”they've been poisoned
entry.summary:
Rescuers capture a sick sea lion in Santa Barbara, California. Hundreds of animals have become ill from a neurotoxin, found in algae blooms, that causes concerning behavioral changes. Two beachgoers have been bitten. A common neurotoxin produced by algae blooms is making California sea lions more aggressive. Hereâ€™s why it has the power to change behaviorâ€”and the danger it poses.
Â
RJ LaMendola, a 40-year-old photographer, was surfing north of Los Angeles last month when a sea lion charged at him and bit his backside through his wetsuit. The sea lion stalked LaMendola as he desperately tried to paddle to shore, keeping the board between himself andÂ the animal.Â
â€œI donâ€™t know how to describe the fear that gripped me at that moment, staring into the face of this creature thaâ€¦

entry.title: Here's why pro photographers obsess over this camera bag
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
For seven years, I relied on my trusty camera bag to accompany me to all the remote places around the world where I reported travel and adventure stories. Last year, it finally broke and I discovered that it had been discontinued. That sent me on an unexpectedly trying mission to find an alternative. There are plenty of camera bags, but as an adventure travel journalist and photographer, I couldnâ€™t get just any bag.Â
I needed a weather-resistant caâ€¦

entry.title: Ancient walking trails are backâ€”and you can hike them
The Louvre is a gastronomic journeyâ€”if you know where to look
In Fiji, these hotels put the guests to work (in a good way)
entry.summary: Tourism Fiji's new initiative is rooted in the local concept of loloma, meaning to act with generosity, driven by love, and aims to inspire visitors to help conserve and protect the local flora and fauna. From mangrove nurseries to manta ray protection, these 6 hotels invite guests to help protect the local land and animals. Fijiâ€™s gin-bottle-blue waters, luminous sand, and riotously colorful rainforests have long made it a dream destination. But even paradise needs protection â€” the archipelago faces significant threats from climate change, ranging from rising sea levels encroaching on low-lying habitats to coral bleaching damaging the reefs that sustain marine life and shield shorelines from erosion. Thatâ€™s why hotels across Fiji are inviting guests to be pâ€¦

entry.title: Is this the most beautiful bookstore in the world?
entry.summary:
Luigi FrizzoÂ was warnedÂ that the property he was about to lease could be in a flood zone because of its proximity to the water and rising sea levels in in Venice, Italy. It actually sparked his decision to name his bookstoreÂ Acqua AltaÂ (High Tide).
In addition to coming up with his bookshop's name, Frizzo also took proactive steps to create a flood-proof infrastructure plan to protectÂ more thanÂ 5,000 books, including first editions published more than a century ago.Â He decided to storeÂ hundreds of booksÂ in bathtubs andÂ gondolas,Â longÂ row boatsÂ that have provided transportation throughÂ Venice'sÂ narrow canals since the 11th century.Â
In case you didn't know, Acqua AltaÂ is locatedÂ less than a mile north of Piazza San Marco, the principal public square in Venice. It's easily flooded â€¦

entry.title: Archaeologists found another Egyptian royal tombâ€”but whose is it?
entry.summary:
The discovery of the tomb of an ancient pharaohâ€”the second report in as many monthsâ€”leads a recent spate of archaeological finds from Egypt and casts new light on a formative period of the civilization along the Nile.
In December and January, a team of American and Egyptian archaeologists excavated the roughly 3,600-year-old tomb near the Abydos archaeological site, on the edge of the desert west of the Nile and about 20 miles northwest of the modern city of Luxor in southern Egypt. Egypt's antiquities ministry announced the find in a Facebook post last month.
But the name of the pharaoh who was once entombed there is unknown, as are many of the details about the dynasty of kings he belonged to.
"Egypt was broken apart into multiple rival kingdoms when these kings were rulinâ€¦

entry.title: The day that forced Americans to confront a hidden threat
entry.summary:
FBI agents lead Timothy McVeigh from the courthouse after he was charged with the April 1995 bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. McVeigh, who was convicted of the bombing that killed 168 people, wasn't a foreign agent but rather a homegrown terrorist with anti-government views. Itâ€™s been 30 years since Timothy McVeigh bombed the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building, an attack that reawakened the nation to the dangers of domestic terrorism.
At 9:02 a.m. on April 19, 1995, a bomb ripped open the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City. The explosion took the lives of 168 people, including 19 young children. It would go down as one of the deadliest terrorist attacks in U.S. history.
It also forced Americans to grapple with an uncomâ€¦

entry.title: Why you should visit Mississaugaâ€”Canada's lakeside city
entry.summary:
While Mississaugaâ€™s sleek yet modest skyline and expansive waterfront might not be as well known as the limelight-stealing attractions of neighbouring Toronto, this attractive city on the shores of Lake Ontario has plenty to offer. As home to the countryâ€™s largest airport, it serves as the entry point for many travellers to Canada, but thereâ€™s much to reward visitors who stick around, with more than 500 wildlife-filled parks, an international food scene and Niagara Falls just across the water, plus a vibrant schedule of year-round markets and festivals. Hereâ€™s what not to miss in Mississauga.
In the heart of the city, Riverwood Parkâ€™s 150 acres features curated gardens blooming with rhododendrons, as well as forests, wetlands and meadows hiding herons, sandpipers, hawks, owls anâ€¦

entry.title: Where to travel in May
entry.summary:
May is the month that signals the start of summer in Europeâ€™s coastal resorts. Summer is on the way, with Europe's beach resorts dusting off their sun loungers, marine life gathering for feeding seasons and a packed programme of seaside festivals and arts events around the world to tempt travellers.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Temperatures in Mediterranean, Aegean and Ionian waters start to rise, many of the regionâ€™s lidos and beach clubs open, and Ibiza's superclub season gets underway with big launch parties.
There are plenty of seaside arts festivals kicking off, too. Notably Brighton Festival (3-26 May 2025) in the UK â€” a mega multi-arts event taking over the Sussex coastal city, with a programme large enough to warrant its own fâ€¦

entry.title: Lebanon: UN expresses deep concern over latest Israeli airstrikes, in call for restraint
entry.summary: The United Nations on Tuesday expressed deep concern over the latest escalation of violence in Lebanon, despite the fragile ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah, following an Israeli airstrike in southern Beirut that reportedly killed four people â€“ including a woman â€“ and injured several others.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Surging violence as armed groups target civilians in the east, Human Rights Council hears
entry.summary: Civilians continue to bear the brunt of the violence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) with 602 victims of extrajudicial or summary executions in North and South Kivu recorded over just two months, theÂ Human Rights Council heard on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan on brink of famine as fighting ravages Darfur, UN warns
entry.summary: The humanitarian crisis in Sudan is spiralling as rival militaries continue to battle for control of the country, with the UN expressing profound alarm on Monday over escalating hostilities, particularly in North Darfur.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres calls for greater equality and inclusion as world marks Autism Awareness Day
entry.summary: Although people with autism are making enormous contributions to societies across the globe, they still face significant challenges.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN-backed forum seeks to boost resilience of worldâ€™s Least Developed Countries
entry.summary: Policymakers, researchers, the private sector and other stakeholders are meeting in Zambiaâ€™s capital, Lusaka, over the next three days to chart a path toward sustainable development and resilience for the worldâ€™s Least Developed Countries (LDCs).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza aid worker killings: One humanitarian still missing in mass grave
entry.summary: UN humanitarians and partners on Tuesday expressed deep shock at the killing of 15 colleagues on duty in southern Gaza by Israeli forces whoseÂ remains were recovered on Sunday from a shallow grave after a week-long rescue operation, noting that one worker is still missing.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar earthquake latest: Entire communities flattened, aid teams say
entry.summary: As the death toll continues to rise in Myanmar after last Friday's earthquake tragedy, UN humanitarians have been rushing to support severely deprived and traumatized victims, warning that the window for lifesaving response is closing.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: How to save money while traveling
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Travel can be rewarding, but it can also be expensive. The cost can ramp up when you factor in gear and supplies you may need for specialized excursions, like trekking or kayaking. If you do have to shop for an upcoming trip, it pays to be strategic.Â
â€œBuying affordable, high-quality, multipurpose travel gear means spending less money on products pre-trip,â€ says Sunny Fitzgerald, a travel writer who splits her time between Jordan, Costa Rica, and Hâ€¦

entry.title: At these Alpine spas, ancient remedies have a modern twist
entry.summary:
At 95Â°F, the air is charged with a tangerine tang as a man twists and whirls a towel like a whip, unleashing blasts of hot air to the beat of jungle drums. This is Aufguss: a multi-sensory sauna ritual thatâ€™s part purification, part fever-dream.
Deep in the Dolomites â€” the UNESCO-capped mountains â€” wellness has long been part of the landscape itself. Here, ancient remedies are reimagined with a contemporary twist and a touch of the surreal, all infused with the rugged spirit of the Alps.Â
The journey begins in Bolzano, capital of South Tyrol and gateway to the Dolomites. A melting pot of Italian and German culture, locals toast beer and wine in Piazza Walther, savor boiled dumplings at Batzen HÃ¤usl, and cycle down cobblestone streets beneath sweeping mountains. Its most famous â€¦

entry.title: See a different side of Ibiza with a stay in its historic capital
entry.summary:
Ibiza Town was founded by the Phoenicians in the seventh century. See another side of the Balearic Islands with a trip to Ibizaâ€™s whitewashed capital, where winding streets lead to remnants of empires past.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Founded on the White Isleâ€™s southeastern coast by seventh-century Phoenicians, Ibiza Town â€” known to locals as Eivissa â€” is one of Spainâ€™s oldest cities. Over the centuries, Mediterranean tides brought countless conquerors to its shores, many of whom left their mark on Dalt Vila, the cityâ€™s fortified, UNESCO-listed old quarter. And yet, such is Ibizaâ€™s beach-holiday and clubbing fame that its capitalâ€™s historical riches, along with its flourishing culinary scene and quietly bohemian energy, continue to fly uâ€¦

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: Pew Research Center is a subsidiary of The Pew Charitable Trusts, its primary funder. This is the latest report in Pew Research Centerâ€™s ongoing investigation of the state of news, information and journalism in the digital age, a research program funded by The Pew Charitable Trusts, with generous support from the John S. and James [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 164 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Feb. 24 to March 2, 2025. A total of 5,123 panelists responded out of 5,737 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Most Americans Say They Are Tuned In to News About the Trump Administration
entry.summary: Far fewer are hearing about the administrationâ€™s relationship with the media than was the case early in President Donald Trumpâ€™s first term. The post Most Americans Say They Are Tuned In to News About the Trump Administration appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Would you stay at this lighthouse on a remote Tuscan island?
entry.summary:
Faro Capel Rosso is both a functioning lighthouse and a guesthouse. Play castaway on an Italian island, where you can spot whales from a stylish Tuscan retreat set in a working lighthouse.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
This unique retreat â€“ a converted lighthouse on the southernmost tip of Giglio island â€“ comes with its own helipad. But for your average traveller, making pilgrimage to its remote setting is integral to its charm. Travel out to the Tuscan isthmus of Argentario for the ferry from Porto Santo Stefano, an hour across the turquoise Tyrrhenian to arrive in Giglio Port. Follow the islandâ€™s coastal road until it turns to a red sandy trail at Punta di Capel Rosso, where itâ€™s a steep hike down through groves of cliff-clinging cactus tâ€¦

entry.title: Myanmar earthquake: Search and rescue efforts continue in race against time
entry.summary: The human toll of the earthquake which devastated central Myanmar continues to rise, UN humanitarians warned on Sunday, putting more pressure on nearly 20 million people who were already in need of aid.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Why this Greek island is perfect for families
entry.summary:
Cameo Island, part of the National Marine Park of Zakynthos, is connected to the mainland by a wooden bridge. Discover the dramatic caves, storied monasteries and hands-on activities that make the south of Zakynthos such a family-friendly Greek getaway.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A Greek island holiday will feature on many travellersâ€™ wish lists, but families may find themselves bewildered by choice â€” there are more than 6,000 of them, with 227 being inhabited. Part of the Ionian archipelago and easily reached by a direct flight, mid-size Zakynthos ticks all the boxes â€” its southern peninsulas of Keri and Vassilikos are particularly well-served by diverse landscapes and stellar beaches, rich (partly Venetian) history and varied activitieâ€¦

entry.title: Explore the Maya ruins of Guatemala's PetÃ©n department
entry.summary:
The fall of the ancient Maya civilisation came gradually â€” as did the disappearance of its centres of power, each one slowly reclaimed by the creeping jungle. Mighty cities were lost for centuries, biding their time beneath thick drapes of vines and moss like dust sheets. In Guatemala, after the curtain was drawn back, hoards of artefacts eventually made their way to the National Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology in Guatemala City, one of the largest troves of Maya antiques. But other relics wound up in much smaller collections â€” like the one I come across by chance on a small private island in Lake PetÃ©n ItzÃ¡, far from the capital in the countryâ€™s wild north.
I first spy the isle from the bigger, neighbouring island of Flores, home to a namesake port town. Iâ€™m in the city as a gateâ€¦

entry.title: Taste spring around the world with these 5 new cookbooks
entry.summary:
Clockwise from left: Monsoon by Asma Khan, Lugma by Noor Murad, Cook Korea! by Billy Law, La Cocina Vasca by MarÃ­a JosÃ© Sevilla, Caribe by Keshia Sakarah These are the cookbooks to have this spring.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The third cookbook from Asma Khan â€” chef and owner of London restaurant Darjeeling Express â€” is split into six sections, one for each of the Bengali seasons: the familiar four, plus monsoon and dry season. Cooking this way is intuitive for Khan, who grew up eating seasonally in Kolkata, the capital of Indiaâ€™s West Bengal state. Starting with grishsho (summer), light dishes like courgette paratha give way to beef isthu (a mild beef stew) and pumpkin dal, before readers progress into the bÃ´rsha (monsoon) and shÃ´rot â€¦

entry.title: How to spend 4 days in St John's, Canada
entry.summary:
Find humongous humpbacks and pint-sized puffins at home among icebergs adrift in the Atlantic in Newfoundland and Labrador. Canadaâ€™s easternmost province beckons travellers to explore its wealth of seaboard towns, towering lighthouses and historic landmarks, as well as to experience its rich culture and heritage.
The provinceâ€™s main gateway and largest city, St. Johnâ€™s, is surprisingly close to London (with a flight time of roughly five hours), yet the city and the surrounding Avalon Peninsula are a world apart. For those who like to travel by road, a four-day itinerary encapsulates the best of this independently minded province. Come for the fish and chips and Celtic-tinged folk sessions, stay for the quirky delicacies, like iceberg-brewed lagers, and the time-honoured traditions sucâ€¦

entry.title: Looking beyond GDP to reach the Sustainable Development Goals
entry.summary: Countries should consider looking beyond Gross Domestic Product, or GDP, as the key measure of economic growth to achieve the ambitious Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), UN policymakers have suggested.

entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Saturday strongly condemned an attack on peacekeepers serving with UN mission MINUSCA in the Central African Republic which left one Kenyan â€˜blue helmetâ€™ dead.

entry.title: Myanmar quake: More than 1,600 reported killed, as UN aid operation supports rescue efforts
entry.summary: Latest news reports indicate that over 1,600 have been killed in Myanmar with thousands injured following two powerful earthquakes on Friday which have left hundreds trapped under rubble.

entry.title: Unlock the secrets of longevity in these destinations
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Longevity travel is one of the biggest trends of the year, as peopleÂ worldwide become ever more fascinated with living aÂ longer, fuller life. Many are spending significant sums, investing in state-of-the-art tests and biohacking treatments thatÂ claim to help you extend your lifespan. But what if you couldÂ live to 100 and still enjoy good health without the intervention of science orÂ tech?
Deep in the south of Japan, miles away from the mainland, lies the subtropical island of Okinawa. A slow-paced paradise hugged by pristine beaches, itâ€™s home to a community of islanders that can teach us a thing or two about living well. Okinawa is one of the five original â€˜Blue Zoneâ€™ destinations, a handful of places where peoplâ€¦

entry.title: Haiti reaches â€˜yet another crisis pointâ€™ as gangs tighten their grip
entry.summary: The UN human rights chief sounded the alarm on Thursday over the rapidly deteriorating situation in Haiti, calling it a â€œcatastropheâ€ fuelled by gang violence, widespread impunity and a political process that is hanging by a thread.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Despite renewed conflict in eastern DR Congo, protection for civilians is paramount: Keita
entry.summary: As the conflict in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) has intensified in recent months, the UN peacekeeping mission, MONUSCO, has been working to protect civilians - including in areas under the control of the Rwandan-backed M23 armed group in North Kivu province.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Tens of millions risk starvation as funding cuts deepen crises in DR Congo: WHO, WFP
entry.summary: Sharply declining aid could force tens of millions across the globe who rely on food aid into extreme hunger and starvation, the World Food Programme (WFP) warned on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Perfect stormâ€™ in South Sudan demands urgent action, says Guterres
entry.summary: Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres warned on Friday of a rapidly deteriorating crisis in South Sudan, calling for urgent dialogue, the immediate release of detained officials and renewed commitment to the 2018 peace agreement.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 47 million health workers and advocates call for cleaner air to curb pollution deaths
entry.summary: Over 50 countries, cities, and organizations pledged new commitments on Thursday to tackle air pollution, protect public health, and help halve its deadly impacts by 2040 â€“ a goal backed by a petition from 47 million health professionals, patients and advocates demanding clean air be made a public health priority.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Acts of war bear hallmarks of atrocity crimes, warn UN humanitarians
entry.summary: Lifesaving supplies in Gaza continue to run dangerously low, nearly four weeks into the total aid blockade and deadly bombardment of the enclave by Israel, UN humanitarians said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN teams ramp up response to deadly quake in Myanmar and Thailand
entry.summary: Amid reports of hundreds dead or missing following a 7.7 magnitude earthquake with its epicentre in central Myanmar, UN teams in the region are â€œresponding fastâ€, said UN relief chief Tom Fletcher on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Extreme weather impacts cascading â€˜from the Andes to the Amazonâ€™
entry.summary: Extreme weather and climate impacts had a damaging toll on Latin America and the Caribbean last year, resulting in dying glaciers, record-breaking hurricanes, debilitating drought and deadly floods, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) said in a new report on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Tariffs: Job protectors or trade killers?
entry.summary: The word â€œtariffâ€ has been catapulted from the business pages to the headlines over the last few months, as major economies impose or threaten them on other nations. But tariffs are not just a blunt weapon to be used in geopolitical brinkmanship: they can, if used effectively, help poorer countries develop their economies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Fast fashion fuelling global waste crisis, UN chief warns
entry.summary: Fast fashion is accelerating an environmental catastrophe, with the equivalent of one garbage truckâ€™s worth of clothing either incinerated or sent to landfill every second, the UN chief warned on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: UN humanitarians flag impact on children of return to war
entry.summary: The UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) issued a warning on Thursday over the terrible impact on youngsters of renewed Israeli bombardment and the total aid blockade.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Armed groups install â€˜parallel administrationâ€™ in DR Congo, Security Council hears
entry.summary: Armed groups affiliated with Rwanda-backed M23 rebels in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) have continued to expand theirÂ control in North and South Kivu â€“ setting their sights on more territorial gains.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war: Displacement figures fall for first time
entry.summary: For the first time in nearly two years of brutal conflict the number of Sudanese internally displaced during nearly two years of brutal conflict between rival militaries has fallen, the UN International Organization for Migration (IOM) reported on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Record numbers face acute or emergency hunger
entry.summary: A recordÂ 27.7 million people are in the grip of acute hunger inÂ the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), amid ongoing conflict linked to massive displacement and rising food prices,Â global food security experts warned on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights body sounds the alarm over South Sudan crisis
entry.summary: The UN Commission on Human Rights in South Sudan issued an alert on Thursday over the the rapidly escalating crisis in the country, calling for urgent coordinated action to protect civilians and preserve the 2018 peace deal that ended five years of civil war.

entry.title: How Two Graduate Reporters Exposed a System Used to Hide Police Officer Misconduct
entry.summary: Two reporters, nominated for the 2025 Goldsmith Prize, spent years investigating legal agreements in California that hide police officers' past misconduct from the public.

entry.title: Where to eat the best lobster roll in Boston
entry.summary: Hailing from Massachusetts, the lobster roll has been a popular snack with locals for generations. Visitors to Boston can try it in its place of origin, with the city's restaurants offering showstopping versions of this legendary sandwich.

entry.title: See how Muslims celebrate Eid al-Fitr around the world
entry.summary: From beachside prayers in Senegal to colorful festivals in Pakistan, these pictures show the many ways that Muslims observe the end of the holy month of Ramadan.

entry.title: Donâ€™t paddle out without these key kayak accessories
entry.summary: The right extras, from grippy gloves to an insect repelling sunhat, can step up your next adventure.

entry.title: A space telescope just found a treasure trove of galaxies
entry.summary: Euclid, a European space telescope, just captured 26 million galaxies to reveal the secrets of the dark universe.

entry.title: Scientists want to poison mosquitosâ€”with human blood
entry.summary: Low doses of a drug already approved for treating rare genetic conditions in humans kills mosquitoes dead. Scientists say it could be a valuable new tool in the fight against disease.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 164 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Feb. 24 to March 2, 2025. A total of 5,123 panelists responded out of 5,737 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Personal impacts of deportations and arrests on U.S. adults
entry.summary: This chapter explores whether U.S. adults worry about being asked to prove their U.S. citizenship or immigration status during their daily routine and if they believe deportations of immigrants living in the United States illegally will make their lives better or worse. Do people worry they or someone close to them might be deported? About [â€¦] The post 2. Personal impacts of deportations and arrests on U.S. adultsÂ Â Â appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report was written by Luis Noe-Bustamante, research associate, and Jens Manuel Krogstad, senior writer/editor. Editorial guidance was provided by Mark Hugo Lopez, director, race and ethnicity research; Sahana Mukherjee, associate director, race and ethnicity research; and Jocelyn Kiley, director, political research. The report was reviewed by Neha Sahgal, vice president, research; and Rachel (Weisel) [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Views on deportations and arrests of immigrants in the U.S. illegally
entry.summary: This chapter explores Americansâ€™ views on which groups of immigrants who are in the country illegally should be deported, where arrests should be allowed, and whether police should be able to check a personâ€™s immigration status. Views on whether immigrants living in the country illegally should be deported About half of U.S. adults (51%) say [â€¦] The post 1. Views on deportations and arrests of immigrants in the U.S. illegally appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Americansâ€™ Views of Deportations
entry.summary: Most say arrests of immigrants living in the U.S. illegally should be allowed at protests or in homes, but not at places of worship or schools. The post Americansâ€™ Views of Deportations appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Take the train from Paris to Milan on Europe's 'style express'

entry.summary: Scientists have learned that particles from car tires are a leading culprit in salmon declines in the Pacific Northwestâ€”and are in our bodies as well.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This analysis was produced by Pew Research Center as part of the Pew-Templeton Global Religious Futures project, which analyzes religious change and its impact on societies around the world. Funding for the Global Religious Futures project comes from The Pew Charitable Trusts and the John Templeton Foundation (grant 63095). This publication does not necessarily reflect [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Centerâ€™s Spring 2024 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on telephone, face-to-face and online interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates, Social Research Centre and Verian. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Read more details about ourÂ international survey methodology and country-specific sample [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 6. Religious switching into and out of Judaism
entry.summary: Find out what percentage of adults have joined or left Judaism, or remained Jewish since childhood, in the U.S. and Israel. The post 6. Religious switching into and out of Judaism appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. Religious switching into and out of Hinduism
entry.summary: Find out what percentage of adults have joined or left Hinduism, or remained Hindu since childhood, in four countries. The post 5. Religious switching into and out of Hinduism appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Religious switching into and out of Buddhism
entry.summary: Find out what percentage of adults have joined or left Buddhism, or remained Buddhist since childhood, in six countries. The post 3. Religious switching into and out of Buddhism appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Religious switching into and out of Islam
entry.summary: Find out what percentage of adults have joined or left Islam, or remained Muslim since childhood, in 13 countries. The post 4. Religious switching into and out of Islam appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Religious switching into and out of the religiously unaffiliated group
entry.summary: Read about where religiously unaffiliated populations have had the largest net gains, and how those who've joined the "nones" identified previously. The post 2. Religious switching into and out of the religiously unaffiliated group appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Religious switching into and out of Christianity
entry.summary: Read about where Christianity has had the largest net losses, and how those who've left Christianity now identify religiously. The post 1. Religious switching into and out of Christianity appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Around the World, Many People Are Leaving Their Childhood Religions
entry.summary: In many places surveyed, 20% or more of all adults have left their childhood religious group. Christianity and Buddhism have had especially large losses. The post Around the World, Many People Are Leaving Their Childhood Religions appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Biological weapons â€˜must not only be unthinkable but also impossibleâ€™
entry.summary: The world came together 50 years ago to ban biological weapons and in todayâ€™s volatile geopolitical climate we can ill-afford to let this moral safeguard â€œerodeâ€,Â the UNâ€™sÂ High Representative for Disarmament Affairs said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN calls for immediate ceasefire as South Sudan edges closer to renewed civil war
entry.summary: The UN Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) on Wednesday called for an immediate end to hostilities and urgent dialogue between the countryâ€™s leaders to prevent a relapse into civil war, as violence escalates around the capital city.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: Rights chief deplores deadly army strikes on North Darfur market
entry.summary: The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights has again called for greater protection of civilians in war-torn Sudan following deadly army airstrikes in North Darfur earlier this week.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN welcomes Black Sea talks, warns of worsening humanitarian crisis in Ukraine
entry.summary: The United Nations on Wednesday welcomed recent diplomatic talks involving Russia, Ukraine and the United States in Saudi Arabia, calling an agreement on freedom of navigation and security in the Black Sea a crucial step for global food security.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Renewables are renewing economiesâ€™, UN chief tells top climate forum
entry.summary: Ministers from 40 countries met on Wednesday at the first major climate forum of 2025 to discuss progress in renewable energy generation and the rising toll of inaction over rising temperatures.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Pact for the Future: Countries urged to translate pledges into action
entry.summary: UN Member States met on Wednesday for the first of three key meetings to advance a global agreement that pledges concrete actions to achieve a safer, more peaceful, sustainable and inclusive world for generations to come.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Deadly impacts of childhood stunting can be prevented, WFP insists
entry.summary: Childhood stunting from malnutrition is a global but preventable problem if adequate investment can be found, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) said on Wednesday, amid chronic funding shortages that threaten essential feeding programmes.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen: Ten Years of War, a Lifetime of Loss
entry.summary: Marking a decade of war in Yemen, Othman Belbeisi, Regional Director for Middle East and North Africa at the UN International Organization for Migration (IOM), highlights the resilience of its people, the deepening humanitarian crisis, and the urgent need for global action.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: No aid has reached war-torn enclave for more than three weeks
entry.summary: It has now been three and a half weeks since Israel imposed a complete blockade on all aid into Gaza, despite daily efforts by UN humanitarians to secure fresh access, they said in anÂ update from the shattered enclave.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Can renewable energy survive climate change?
entry.summary: As droughts reduce hydropower and clouds dim solar output around the world, experts say meteorology and climate science must be at the heart of the energy transition.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 7 wild herbs you can forage in the UK

entry.title: Why raw pet food isn't worth the risk
entry.summary:
A Maine Coon cat enjoys mealtime. Four house cats have died from H5N1 in cases linked to raw pet food, and experts say itâ€™s not worth the risk.  A recent case of bird flu was linked to a cat's raw food diet. Experts stress there are other health risks, too.
Pet owners on TikTok who feed their cats and dogs raw food regularly show off theirÂ colorful bowls, full of uncooked meats, organs, heads, feet, or bones.Â
The $3.1 billion global raw pet food industry has always been controversial, since the food contains animal protein that hasnâ€™t been cooked or heated enough to kill germs. But a recent link to bird flu is sounding a new alarm.Â Â
In December, a pet food company recalled a batch of its raw turkey frozen food after itÂ tested positive for H5N1, the highly deadly biâ€¦

entry.title: 7 cruises for foodies and wine lovers
entry.summary:
Some of the best food and wine cruises of 2025 include chef-led demonstrations, wine tastings, culinary classes, and more. Sail through the heart of the Pacific Northwest wine region. Sip wine on a river cruise through Bordeaux. These itineraries offer something for everyone.
When it comes to cruising, thereâ€™s a style, ship, and itinerary for everyone. Long gone are the days of massive buffets and sub-par dining. Cruise ships are now culinary beacons where guests can try new cuisines on and off the vessel. Every year, it seems the wine and culinary cruise options keep improving. Some of the best itineraries in 2025 include wine tasting on a river cruise through Bordeaux, sailing through the heart of the Columbia and Snake rivers for regional wine tastings, and cruising around the Mâ€¦

entry.title: 10 of the best hotels in the Cotswolds, England's rural getaway
entry.summary:
From renowned produce to quintessential rural charm, the Cotswolds is the perfect English country getaway. The bucolic region in southwest England is home to some of the countryâ€™s most characterful accommodation, from charming pubs with rooms to retro-themed manor houses.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Cotswolds fulfils every picture of rural England you might care to conjure. Pretty villages of ancient stone houses curl around country lanes, with low hills rolling between. Handsome market towns brim with antique shops and coaching inns. Sweeping over six counties in the south west, the region was made rich in the Middle Ages by the wool trade, and retains an air of unruffled, comfortable respectability. The Cotswoldsâ€™ quality produce haâ€¦

author.name: Amanda Canning, George Clode, Sam Kemp, Angela Locatelli, Georgia Stephens, Orla Thomas

entry.title: We found great travel gear for well under $100
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*
Amazonâ€™s Big Spring Sale runs March 25-31, just in time to grab discounts for upcoming spring and summer travels. The best part? Many of our favorite travel and outdoor essentials are on sale. From travel bags and tech to gear, here are all our top picks for well under $100. Before you buy, remember that shopping on Amazon has an environmental impact. Be sure to check out our tips for shopping sustainably.
Fully charged, this foldable solar â€¦

entry.title: A guide to Denverâ€™s famed Red Rocks Amphitheatre
entry.summary: From Bono and Bonnie Raitt to The Beach Boys and The Beatles, world-class performances are part and parcel of the small sandstone outcrop on the edge of Colorado's Rocky Mountain foothills. Set in a red landscape of high-desert and sheer cliffs 15 miles from Denver, the 9,525-capacity Red Rocks Amphitheatre has won Pollstarâ€™s award for best outdoor venue so many times that the award was renamed the 'Red Rocks Award'. And while Red Rocks found fame in the 20th century as a music venue, the areaâ€™s storied past spans millennia. Though nothing can compare to catching a live show, paying a visit to Red Rocks in the daytime offers a whole other experience, with the surrounding Red Rocks Park offering 738 acres of spectacular mountain scenery, ripe for exploring on foot, mountain bike or horse. Yâ€¦

entry.title: Why are so few African safaris Black-owned?
entry.summary:
A riverside lunch at Zambezi Sands in Zimbabweâ€™s Zambezi National Park highlights the hospitality of Batoka Africa, one of the few Black-owned safari companies on the continent. Founded by Vimbai Masiyiwa, Batoka is part of a growing effort to ensure local communitiesâ€”not just international touristsâ€”benefit from wildlife tourism. While local ownership is growing, Black entrepreneurs remain rare in the billion-dollar safari industry. These trailblazers are pushing for change.
Vimbai Masiyiwa was on a family safari in Zimbabweâ€™s Victoria Falls National Park when a guide made an offhand remark that stuck with her. â€œDonâ€™t worry, itâ€™s a lot more beautiful when we get to the lodge,â€ the guide said. The commentâ€”meant to gloss over the poverty outsideâ€”left Masiyiwa unsettled. Why was the râ€¦

entry.title: This bizarre dinosaur has something in common with modern sloths
entry.summary:
Therizinosaurs were some of the strangest dinosaurs of all time. Descended from carnivores, the prehistoric reptiles were plant-eaters and had fuzzy feathered bodies, small heads with peg-like teeth in their jaws, bulbous stomachs that acted like fermenting vats for heaps of vegetation, and impressively large claws on each of their hands. Their build and claws have drawn comparisons to sloths, but some of these reptiles stood over 13 feet tall and weighed more than five tons. Now paleontologists have uncovered a therizinosaur that stands out even among its unusual relativesâ€”because itâ€™s missing a finger.Â
Described in the journal iScience today, the new dinosaur comes from rocks in Mongoliaâ€™s Gobi Desert that are over 90 million years old. Back in 2012, paleontologists from the Mongolâ€¦

entry.title: Migrant deaths in Asia hit record high in 2024, UN data reveals
entry.summary: The year 2024 marked the deadliest on record for migrants in Asia, with at least 2,514 lives lost along the regionâ€™s perilous migration routes, according to new data from the UN International Organization for Migration (IOM).

entry.summary: The UN human rights office (OHCHR) expressed major concern on Tuesday following the detention of at least 92 people by the Turkish authorities over the past week, including Istanbulâ€™s mayor, Ekrem Ä°mamoÄŸlu, who has been charged with corruption and removed from office.

entry.title: Niger: Mosque attack which killed 44 should be â€˜wake-up callâ€™, says rights chief
entry.summary: UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker TÃ¼rk on Tuesday condemned the recent attack on a mosque in Kokorou village, in western Niger, in which at least 44 worshippers were killed and 20 injured.

entry.title: â€˜Fragility and hopeâ€™ mark new era in Syria amid ongoing violence and aid struggles
entry.summary: UN Special Envoy for Syria Geir Pedersen briefed the Security Council on Tuesday, pointing to the devastating violence on the coast earlier this month, which marked a grim new chapter in Syriaâ€™s fragile transition to a lasting peace.

entry.title: Crimes of the transatlantic slave trade â€˜unacknowledged, unspoken and unaddressedâ€™
entry.summary: The transatlantic slave trade may have ended centuries ago but its legacy is ever present, the UN Secretary-General said on Tuesday, marking the International Day of Remembrance for its victims.

entry.title: Aid operations stretched to the limit in Burundi by ongoing DR Congo crisis
entry.summary: With thousands fleeing violence in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) across the border into Burundi, aid operations are stretched to the limit, the World Food Programme (WFP)Â said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Yemen: One in two children severely malnourished after 10 years of war
entry.summary: In Yemen, a decade of conflict has proved catastrophic for the countryâ€™s children living under the threat of airstrikes and staggeringly high malnutrition rates, the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Decades of progress in reducing child deaths and stillbirths at risk, UN warns
entry.summary: The number of children around the world dying before their fifth birthday stands at a record low â€“ but this achievement is under threat due to a chronic lack of investment in routine humanitarian work and interventions, the head of the UN Children's Fund (UNICEF), said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Creating a New Nonprofit Outlet to Investigate Wildlife Crime
entry.summary: With legacy media stepping back from the space, three veteran reporters decided to create a new outlet dedicated to wildlife investigations. Rachael Bale, one of the co-founders of WIRE, explains why.

entry.title: How to sleep better while traveling
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Getting enough sleep can be a real challenge, even on a good day. Quality sleep can be even harder to achieve when youâ€™re traveling. Indeed, only one in three travelers report sleeping well.Â
â€œTravel is often about new experiences and environments, which is great for the soul and terrible for the body, particularly the sleeping body,â€ says Erica Huss, a wellness expert and host of the podcast All Too Well. â€œSleep thrives on routine and consistency,â€¦

entry.title: How to travel better: a beginner's guide to sustainable travel
entry.summary:
In Europe, where many trains are electric, the emissions from rail travel can be as much as 10 times less than flying. Sustainable, green, responsible â€” planet-friendly ways to explore the world are more popular than ever but how do you start to make better decisions when you travel? The first step is to understand what sustainable travel is and why itâ€™s important.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Sustainable travel is about travelling in a way thatâ€™s sensitive to the climate and nature emergencies while ensuring that the wellbeing of the places we visit gain long-term benefit from us travelling there. Itâ€™s a balancing act between maximising the positives of travel while reducing or eliminating the negatives.
The concentration of carbonâ€¦

entry.title: Startling Antarctic sea creatures found beneath huge iceberg
entry.summary:
On January 13, when an iceberg the size of Chicago broke away from Antarcticaâ€™s immense George VI Ice Shelf, scientists in a nearby research vessel did something nobody had ever done. They sailed to look at the seafloor that had suddenly been exposed, like lifting the worldâ€™s biggest rock to see what critters lay underneath.Â
Life is almost everywhere in the oceans, from the sunlit-bathed shallows to the pitch-black, sometimes volcanic depths. The research team aboard the Schmidt Ocean Instituteâ€™s R/VÂ Falkor (too)Â ship were confident theyâ€™d find animals at their destination. But they were shocked at the explosion of life they discoveredâ€”a forest of sponges, giant sea spiders, icefish, octopuses, huge corals, anemones, and ethereal deep-sea jellyfish.
Marine biology is known to beâ€¦

8 spectacular places in the U.S. to see spring flowers in bloom
entry.summary:
The Cascade Volcanic Mountain Range looms behind a field of tulips in Washington's Skagit Valley. From blooms dotting desert cacti to rows of bright pink cherry trees, here's where to see this spring's best flower displays.
With daylight stretching longer and outdoor temperatures ticking upward, spring is in the air. Plants across the United States are quickening their growth, sprouting leaves and flowers as they revive the landscape. Spring will provide chances to admire the colorful transformation. Below are a few of the best places and times to witness the dramatic beauty of flowers in bloom.
Cherry trees in Washington, D.C.
Peak bloom: March, April
Each spring, the U.S. capital hosts the National Cherry Blossom Festival. Across three and a half weeks, 1.5 millionâ€¦

entry.title: Phil Rosenthal on the people, places and dishes that have shaped his life
entry.summary: Philâ€™s European live tour is taking place until 19 April. The writer, producer and host of Somebody Feed Phil talks about eating ants in Tokyo, the legacy of Anthony Bourdain and the best shawarma heâ€™s ever had. This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). I was 17 when I had garlic for the first time. I always equate it to The Wizard of Oz, when Dorothy opens the door and the movie is then in colour. My parents were German immigrants, so we ate old-world German-style cuisine. Things like beef stew, chicken schnitzel, potatoesâ€¦ there was zero spice. Even when we ordered Chinese food, once every three months, it was always the blandest thing on the menu. It wasnâ€™t until I left their house that I had food with flavour. My parents were fantastic in evâ€¦

entry.title: 6 ways to explore Malta
entry.summary:
With its Neolithic history and distinctive limestone landscapes, Malta may seem a destination drawn from the past. But if this resilient archipelago has learnt anything from its numerous occupations, itâ€™s to adapt. On the islands of Malta, Gozo and Comino, centuries-old forts and grand historic palaces now sit side-by-side with modern fine dining restaurants and sleek waterfront promenades. Travellers today are beckoned to explore Maltaâ€™s varied dive sites, hike through otherworldly landscapes or observe the host of international talent set to take the stage at the islandsâ€™ assorted year-round festivals. With so many experiences to choose from, here are six not to miss.
Maltaâ€™s 300 days of sunshine a year mean the islands are ideal for outdoor activity â€” even in the winter, crisâ€¦
