entry.title: This restaurant is Istanbul's trendiestâ€”here's why
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
At Istanbul restaurant Turk, Turkeyâ€™s first and only to have been awarded two Michelin stars, diners are introduced to the breadth and depth of Turkish cuisine. The countryâ€™s rich culinary heritage, diverse landscapes and cornucopia of ingredients inform creative dishes, which interpret this cultural and geographic influence through a modern lens.
The restaurantâ€™s opening was something of a homecoming for chef Fatih Tutak. After a stint cooking in Bangkok, he returned to Turkey in 2019, embarking on a fresh discovery of his country and its cuisine, before launching his own establishment, Turk. â€œI had to find my own way of expressing myself and my home countryâ€™s food,â€ Tutak says.
(Related: these are the best râ€¦

entry.title: Discover 5 of Louisiana's most iconic dishes
entry.summary: Being so uniquely Louisianan, the world-class dishes created in this Southern state are nearly impossible to define simply as American. The cuisine here reflects a varied tapestry of cultures, with the influence of France, Spain, West Africa, the Caribbean, Germany, Italy and Native Americans woven into its distinct recipes. In the west, you have Cajun country, an area populated by Acadians originally from French-speaking Canada. In the north, Southern-style home cooking is the order of the day. Then, thereâ€™s the Creole influence in the lively city of New Orleans. Wherever you head, many dishes are dominated by a slow-cooked roux, and the â€˜holy trinityâ€™, a mixture of onions, peppers and celery â€” Louisianaâ€™s answer to the mirepoix (a base of diced vegetables). Discover this and much more ofâ€¦

entry.title: 3-week Gaza aid ban â€˜collective punishmentâ€™: UNRWA chief
entry.summary: The tight Israeli blockade of humanitarian supplies is pushing Gaza closer to an acute hunger crisis, Philippe Lazzarini, the head of the UN agency for Palestine refugees (UNRWA), said on Sunday.

entry.title: Mind your language: The battle for linguistic diversity in AI
entry.summary: For two years, one international organization under the umbrella of the UN has been leading a relentless campaign in the corridors of global digital diplomacy. Its mission? To bring linguistic diversity to English-dominated artificial intelligence.

entry.title: Why the Croatian island BraÄ is perfect for family getaways
entry.summary:
BraÄâ€™s main port town Supetar hosts a historic harbour with a busy promenade. The island of BraÄ is home to arguably the best beach on Croatiaâ€™s Dalmatian coast, along with crowd-pleasing local cuisine, gentle hikes and island-hopping opportunities that will keep families well entertained.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Just a short ferry-hop from the city of Split, BraÄ was put on the map by its extraordinary Zlatni Rat beach â€” a giant tongue of pebbles that shifts with the tides and winds, making it a remarkable natural phenomenon. But this small Adriatic island is also ideally located for island-hopping, watersports, pootling around in characterful stone villages and active days out to mountain lookouts and along coastal hiking trailâ€¦

entry.title: Fish are once again spinning to death in the Florida Keys
entry.summary:
Dead sawfish washed up on beaches in the Florida Keys last year during a bizarre event where dozens of fish species began exhibiting an odd spinning behavior. Now, sawfish and others are starting to exhibit the behavior again. After nine months, the strange behavior that claimed the lives of endangered sawfish is back. Hereâ€™s what we know about whatâ€™s causing it.
A bizarre fish behavior has resurfaced in the Florida Keys, and scientists are working diligently to uncover the cause and its potential long-term effects.
In fall 2023, fish and rays were seen spinning in circles and swimming erratically. Critically endangered smalltooth sawfish would thrash back and forth and began washing up dead on beaches. The unusual phenomenon affected over 80 species, including snapper, bull sâ€¦

entry.title: These stunts arenâ€™t just magic tricksâ€”theyâ€™re acts of faith
entry.summary:
When Pallaniyammal Sanmugam was pregnant with her second son, her gynecologist advised she would have to undergo a cesarean section. Believing a vaginal delivery would be safer for both her and her baby, Sanmugam prayed to the Hindu god Karthikeya, promising that if she delivered a healthy baby through vaginal delivery, she would express her gratitude by piercing a trident through her body during Panguni Uthiram, a Hindu festival where devotees pierce their bodies with spikes, rods, and needles to pay respects to the god and thank him for fulfilled wishes. Soon, Sanmugamâ€™s wish, too, was fulfilled.Â
â€œThe following year, I had a trident pierced through my abdomen. Iâ€™ve done it 13 times so far, and each time, Iâ€™ve received what Iâ€™d asked for. If my body cooperates, Iâ€™ll do it at least tâ€¦

entry.title: How you can change your body's threshold for pain
entry.summary:
Pain likely began as a curious evolutionary advantage, helping organisms react to injury quickly and escape while also teaching them to avoid similarly harmful situations in the future.
Nowadays, most humans would go to great lengths to avoid feeling pain. But there are some who dedicate their lives to conquering the sensation, pushing their minds and bodies beyond typical physical limits to achieve dangerous, hair-raising feats.Â
Itâ€™s this complex relationship with pain and endurance that renowned magician David Blaine explores in his new documentary series, David Blaine Do Not Attempt. Traveling the world in search of the extraordinary, Blaine discovers how performance can reinvent fear and influence our perception of pain.
David Blaine Do Not Attempt premieres on Nationalâ€¦

entry.title: Scientists reveal a hidden world beneath Antarctica's ice where rivers flow uphill
entry.summary:
Antarcticaâ€™s massive ice sheetÂ looks flat. Although the continentâ€™s expansive layer of iceÂ rises 13,400 feet above sea level near its center, the gentle slopes of that dome are imperceptible to the human eye.
But below that mile-thick ice lies something surprising: a landscape of steep mountains and valleys, traversed by meandering rivers. Those rivers could play a decisive role in how the ice sheet responds to unprecedented warmth.
Scientists now predict that as Antarcticaâ€™s ice sheet melts and thins over the next few decades, those hidden rivers will grow, jump their banks,Â and shift onto new flow paths. This could destabilize large coastal glaciers that control the rate of sea level rise.
â€œThe changesÂ are pretty drastic,â€ says Christine Dow, a glacial hydrologist at the Uâ€¦

entry.title: Why the Mediterranean diet really is the healthiest
entry.summary:
Even if youâ€™re not a fan of hummus, tabouli, or olives, itâ€™s worth giving the Mediterranean diet a chance. Why? Because when it comes to the hierarchy of healthy eating patterns, the Mediterranean diet consistently comes out on top.
In 2025, U.S. News and World Report ranked it #1 overall, as well as giving it first place as the best diet for mental health, for healthy eating, for inflammation, for gut health and for being the easiest diet to follow. Itâ€™s delicious and nutritious, and consuming it is associated with a variety of health benefits. It is also easy to follow and sustainable for the long haul. And you donâ€™t need to live in a Mediterranean country or even leave home to adhere to the eponymous diet or reap its benefits.
(What foods you really need to eat to reduce inflaâ€¦

entry.title: Why penguin poop makes krill swim for their lives
entry.summary:
New research suggests that the presence of penguin poop causes krill to lose their appetite, among other behaviors. A new study shows that the mere presence of poop prompted the crustaceans to launch into evasive maneuvers.
Krill are like the popcorn shrimp of the Southern Oceanâ€”everyone from whales and seals to fish and penguins wants a bite.
But according to a new study, these translucent, pinkie finger-sized crustaceans arenâ€™t as helpless as you might think.
(Life in Antarctica relies on a shrinking supply of krill.)
In Antarcticaâ€™s Palmer Station lab, scientists put wild-caught krill through a series of tests to see if they could identify the presence of a predatorâ€”in this case, AdÃ©lie penguinsâ€”by squirting a slurry of penguin poop into the crustaceansâ€™ tanks. Beâ€¦

entry.title: 7 places to see wildlife in the U.S. this spring
entry.summary:
In Hallo Bay, brown bears graze on sedge grass in Alaska's Katmai National Park, while outdoor enthusiasts watch at a safe distance. From wild ponies in Virginia to bison in Yellowstone, here are seven wildlife-rich destinationsâ€”and tips on how to be a responsible tourist.
Spring is a magical time to witness wildlife in action, as animals emerge from winter and migratory birds return. From paddling alongside wild ponies on Virginiaâ€™s Eastern Shore to spotting baby bison in Yellowstone National Park, here are seven unforgettable adventures that will take you to wildlife-rich spots across the U.S. Keep in mind, however, that the best wildlife encounters happen when you keep a respectful distance and observe responsible practices, so grab your binoculars and get ready for a spring wilâ€¦

entry.title: Omega-3s are great for your healthâ€”but supplements may not be
entry.summary:
Science has proven time and again that omega-3 fatty acids, or omega-3s, can be among the most important parts of a well-balanced diet. The studies show that the healthy fats can helpÂ lower blood pressure,Â improve immunity,Â reduce joint inflammation,Â support mental health, and evenÂ diminish risks of cardiovascular disease and stroke.Â
But most people aren't getting enough. In fact,Â research showsÂ that some 95 percent of kids aren't meeting the recommended levels of omega-3s in their dietâ€”and about 68 percent of adults aren't either.
(How omega-3 fatty acids help reduce inflammation.)
To increase intake, one in five people over age 60 is taking a fish oil supplement regularly and countless younger adults are doing so as wellâ€”causing the worldwide omega-3s supplement market toâ€¦

entry.title: Why ancient pilgrimages are back in vogue in the UK
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As the sun begins to set, the choristers file down St Johnâ€™s Walk, just as they have for the past 500 years. Their cassocks swish softly, their feet tap the worn flagstones and their murmured voices rise towards rafters adorned with angels and griffins. From my room in the medieval cloisters, I follow them along the ancient passage into the cathedral and take a seat in the stalls. The aged wood creaks beneath me, prayer books shuffle quietly in hand and then, evensong begins.
Hereford Cathedral has been a site of pilgrimage since 1320, when Thomas Cantilupe, a former Bishop of Hereford, was canonised. Pilgrimages fell out of favour after the Reformation, and for centuries, no travellers have spent the night here orâ€¦

entry.title: 8 of Europe's best beginner hikes
entry.summary:
Tre Cime di Lavaredo in the Italian Dolomites offers extraordinary scenery at minimum effort. Whether youâ€™re longing for the Austrian Alps, Italian coasts or historic French hilltop towns, these eight easy beginner trails range from short but memorable walks to multi-day adventures through Europeâ€™s most impressive landscapes.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Tempted by the idea of hiking holidays but worry theyâ€™ll be too gruelling? Here are eight beginner-friendly hikes that are less about endurance and more about the simple pleasures of the Great Outdoors. Some will take you just a few hours, others last several days. But regardless of which you choose to tackle, each has been chosen for their combination of easy terrain, well-maintained pathâ€¦

entry.title: UNICEF condemns looting of lifesaving supplies for children in Sudan
entry.summary: The UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) on Friday strongly condemned the looting of vital humanitarian supplies from Al Bashair Hospital in the Sudanese capital, Khartoum, warning that the theft puts thousands of malnourished children and mothers at risk.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜The poison of racism continues to infect our worldâ€™, Guterres warns on International Day
entry.summary: The United Nations commemorated the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination on Friday, calling on the global community to uphold its shared responsibility to combat racism in all its forms.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Middle East crisis spirals amid mounting civilian deaths, aid blockade
entry.summary: The Israel-Palestine conflict is descending further into violence, with mounting civilian casualties in the West Bank and a deepening humanitarian crisis in Gaza, the UNâ€™s top envoy for the region warned on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Children, refugees pay hefty price of global aid funding crisis
entry.summary: Children, refugees and displaced people worldwide are paying the price for the deep-seated funding crisis that has engulfed the international aid sector, made worse by pronounced cuts in Washington, the UN childrenâ€™s and refugee agencies said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Running to bomb shelters, nothing new for Ukraineâ€™s schoolchildren
entry.summary: Classes cut short by air raid sirens have become a routine part of school life for many Ukrainian youngsters in the three years since Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion began,Â a new UN report published on Friday details.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Exhausted Gazans wake from another night of Israeli bombing: UN aid teams
entry.summary: Israelâ€™s renewed bombing campaign and intensifying ground operation in Gaza are reversing gains achieved during the brief ceasefire, UN humanitarians inside the devastated enclave said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WORLD WATER DAY LIVE: â€˜A cold hard truthâ€™
entry.summary: Melting glaciers, climate crises and access to clean water are some of the messages emerging ahead of World Water Day and the first ever World Day for Glaciers. entry.title: Telltale Data Signs of Bogus Scientific Papers and Fraudulent Academic Research
entry.summary: Two scientists and an editor spent six months investigating so-called paper mills, which churn out bogus scientific papers that impede actual research on lifesaving breakthroughs.

author.name: Frederik Joelving, Cyril LabbÃ©, and Guillaume Cabanac, The Conversation

entry.title: This Japanese culinary curiosity promises 7 extra years of life
entry.summary:
Despite its dark exterior, the inside of the black egg is surprisingly white. Commercial production of black eggs boiled in the bubbling hot springs of Owakudani began several decades agoâ€”but the longevity myth tied to them stretches back much further.
The first thing that hits you isnâ€™t the sight of the steam rising in ghostly tendrils from the mountainside, nor the warning signs advising visitors of the areaâ€™s volcanic activity. Itâ€™s the scent. A thick, mineral-rich fog clings to the air, an unmistakable reminder that the earth here is very much alive.
Welcome to Owakudani, one of the most otherworldly destinations in Japan. Here the ground exhales plumes of sulfur, the rocky terrain is tinged in shades of ochre and gray, and the regionâ€™s most famous culinary delicacy â€” blaâ€¦

entry.title: How do you save a language from extinction?
entry.summary:
Ingrid Gaup braids dried "shoe grass" to insulate winter boots, a technique SÃ¡mi people have used for generations. Like the efforts to save the Inari SÃ¡mi language, practices like this help keep Indigenous knowledge alive. In the 1990s, fewer than 350 people spoke Inari SÃ¡mi. Today, experts say about 500 people speak the near-extinct language, and the movement to learn it is growing.
In 1996, linguist Marja-Liisa Olthuis had a difficult decision to make. Should she speak to her newborn daughter in Finnish or Inari SÃ¡mi, the endangered language of her Indigenous community?
With only a few hundred speakers left, Inari SÃ¡mi was rarely heard outside a handful of families. Finnish, spoken by millions, would have been the easier choiceâ€”especially since Olthuis had moved away from Laâ€¦

entry.title: It's not too early to make plans for America's 250th birthday in 2026
entry.summary:
Cities and towns all over the United States are getting ready to celebrate the country's big 250th birthday in 2026, and they're doing it early. All over the country, cities and towns are going all out for next yearâ€™s semiquincentennial party. Here are our 9 picks for where to goâ€”and how to start celebrating now.
Many states and cities have bragging rights to being the â€œfirstâ€ and â€œoldestâ€ in the nation for different milestones throughout America's history. And with the big blowout birthday coming up in 2026, theyâ€™re getting ready to show off, including at historic inns where George Washington reallyÂ didÂ spend the night.
In some places, festivities have already been planned. But stay tuned, thereâ€™s a lot more red, white, and blue to be announced; check America250 and the stateâ€¦

entry.title: How cherry blossoms came to the United States
entry.summary: People enjoy an afternoon with cherry blossom trees in bloom at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden on April 24, 2024, in New York City. The cherry blossoms, one of the garden's spring highlights, have reached peak bloom, which will last for a limited time before the ground turns pink with petals. The Japanese sakura trees made their way to America's capital with help from a few unlikely adventurers and advocates. Springtime in Washington, D.C. kicks off every year with the city's famous Cherry Blossom Festival, when the fluffy pink cherry trees around the National Mall and Tidal Basin burst into bloom. Hundreds of thousands flock there to take in the beautiful flowers, making it one of Washington's most well-loved events. It's hard to imagine, but more thâ€¦

entry.title: How do seals know how long to hold their breath?
entry.summary: A new study suggests gray seals (Halichoerus grypus) can sense the level of oxygen in their blood and that the animals change their diving behavior in response.  The sea mammals may actually be able to sense the amount of oxygen in their bloodâ€”something we humans can't do. Seals can do many things humans canâ€™t, of course, but a clever experiment in Scotland has just uncovered a new ability. A study published in Science this week suggests that the marine mammals can sense the amount of oxygen in their blood, and change their diving behavior in response. All animals extract oxygen from the air they breathe in, and release carbon dioxide (CO2) from their blood in the air they exhale. Most mammals canâ€™t directly detect oxygen levels in the blood supplying their tissuesâ€¦

entry.title: Debunking the myths behind Harry Houdini's lifeâ€”and death
entry.summary:
His name is now synonymous with breaking out of impossible situations and surviving death-defying stunts, including one that came with the warning â€œFailure Means a Drowning Death.â€ To his audiences, Harry Houdiniâ€™s skills seemed almost supernatural. But to Houdini himself, an immigrant who embraced showmanship to escape grinding poverty, his abilities were built entirely on intelligence, reason, and meticulous preparation.
Always looking over his shoulder at imitators, Houdini spent his career upping his gameâ€“and the stakes. In 1903, in Russia, he requested to be locked naked in a freezing prison van the tsarist police used to transport prisoners on a three-week trip to Siberia. To the astonishment of the guards, Houdini broke out after 45 minutes. From then on, his acts became riskieâ€¦

entry.title: 25 new ways to see the U.S. in 2025
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Point to any part of Americaâ€™s vast 50-state map and thereâ€™s an adventure to be had. Always experimenting, forever innovating â€” thereâ€™s never a dull moment in the US and this year brings a host of new tours, anniversaries, relaunched trains and overlooked regions to explore. From the surf-lashed West Coast to the vast forests of New York State â€” and all the canyons, vineyards and honky-tonks in between â€” travellers are guaranteed to find their perfect slice of Americana in this list of experiences for the year ahead.
Amtrakâ€™s Southern Gulf coast train is set to become one of the USAâ€™s great rail routes when it reopens in spring 2025, following a 20-year hiatus thanks to the damage wrought by Hurricane Katrina. Thâ€¦

entry.title: End of eternal ice: Many glaciers will not survive this century, climate scientists say
entry.summary: Glaciers in many regions will not survive the 21st century if they keep melting at the current rate, potentially jeopardising hundreds of millions of people living downstream, UN climate experts said on the firstÂ World Day for Glaciers.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Free societies are good for business says UN rights chief, wrapping up visit to Kyrgyzstan
entry.summary: Respect for human rights is not only a moral obligation but a necessity for economic stability, the UNâ€™s top human rights official said on Thursday, during a visit to the Central Asian country of Kyrgyzstan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria's humanitarian crisis: 16.5 million in need amid continuing conflict
entry.summary: The legacy of the Syrian conflict, which saw the overthrow of the Assad regime in December last year, is that 16.5 million people are in dire need of assistance, making it one of the largest humanitarian crises globally, a senior UN humanitarian said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Trailblazers: UNâ€™s â€˜founding mothersâ€™ remind all people to stand up for human rights
entry.summary: Silence is not an option in the fight for human rights â€“ that was the message on Thursday at an event honouring the legacy of the women who have shaped the United Nationsâ€™ commitment to gender equality.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WHO give clean bill of health to cities taking action on preventable diseases
entry.summary: Three cities that share a healthy vision for their residents won UN World Health Organization awards on Thursday for their smoke-free parks, clean air initiatives and obesity-busting school lunch initiatives.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: â€˜Bring them all home nowâ€™, freed hostage tells Security Council
entry.summary: A senior UN political affairs official called for Israel and Hamas to restore the shattered ceasefire in Gaza on Thursday and release all remaining hostages, while one of those freed told the Security Council of his 500-day ordeal in captivity.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: Civilians targeted as hostilities intensify in the capital
entry.summary: Dozens of civilians, including local humanitarian volunteers, have been killed by artillery shelling and aerial bombardment in the eastern part of Sudanâ€™s capital, Khartoum, the UN Human Rights Office (OHCHR) reported on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres welcomes deals to halt energy attacks in Ukraine, Russia
entry.summary: UN chief AntÃ³nio Guterres on Thursday hailed positive announcements from the White House, Kremlin and Kyiv aimed at stopping crippling attacks on energy infrastructure in Ukraine and Russia, linked to Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of its neighbour.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Here are our favorite sandals for men who travel
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
When youâ€™re experiencing new cultures, landscapes, and adventures, your footwear should keep up every step of the way. We think walking sandals offer the perfect mix of comfort and versatility for all your travels.Â
â€œWalking sandals are great because you can wear them around the city, out on a hike, or even to the beach,â€ says Peyton Bergmann, a teacher and avid outdoorsman based in Ypsilanti, Michigan. â€œYou may want to consider certain factors basâ€¦

entry.title: The reason dementia rates are rising is surprisingly simple
entry.summary:
In January, a study published in the journal Nature Medicine suggested that by 2060, the number of Americans with dementia will double to a total of one million. Also doubling: The estimated lifetime risk of developing the condition, compared to previous estimates.
Figures like these can sound scary â€” and indeed, dementia projections carry some warnings. For one, they suggest the U.S. urgently needs to pour resources into growing its caregiving workforce to meet future needs. But paradoxically, this number also tells a success story.
Today, thanks to decades of social and medical progress, more Americans than ever are living long enough to get dementia; in the past, more people would have died of cardiovascular disease or cancer at earlier ages. These health advances have also deâ€¦

entry.title: The best view of the northern lights involves a lot of travelâ€”but it is so worth it
entry.summary:
Peak northern lights viewing in northern Norwary typically happens between November and February. The aurora borealis has jumped to the top of many travelers' wish lists, creating a tourism boom in the northernmost reaches of our planet. This writer found a unique experience in northern Norway.
There are somewhere around one septillion stars in the universe. On a clear night in the middle of a quiet birch forest in northern Norway, it feels as if you can see every single one of them. Tiny dots of starlight on a spectrum of brightness dotted every corner of the night sky in a celestial show that, for me, has only been rivaled by what Iâ€™ve seen in the middle of the American desert, far removed from any source of light.
However, I wasnâ€™t in northern Norway just to stargaze (thougâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Centerâ€™s Spring 2024 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on face-to-face interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates and Verian. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Here are more details about our international survey methodology and country-specific sample designs. The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix E: Best age to retire, by country
entry.summary: The post Appendix E: Best age to retire, by country appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Janell Fetterolf, Senior ResearcherChristine Huang, Research AssociateJordan Lippert, Research AnalystSofia Hernandez Ramones, Research Assistant Peter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerLaura Clancy, Research AnalystManolo Corichi, Research AnalystJonathan Evans, Senior ResearcherMoira Fagan, Research AssociateShannon Greenwood, Digital [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix D: Best age to buy a home, by country
entry.summary: The post Appendix D: Best age to buy a home, by country appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix C: Best age to have a first child, by country
entry.summary: The post Appendix C: Best age to have a first child, by country appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix A: Marriage, childbirth and retirement statistics
entry.summary: To help place the ideal ages provided by respondents in context, we compiled data on when in life people around the world actually get married, have their first child and become eligible for certain retirement benefits. Average age at first marriage comes from the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (DESA), Population Division. [â€¦] The post Appendix A: Marriage, childbirth and retirement statistics appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix B: Best age to get married, by country
entry.summary: The post Appendix B: Best age to get married, by country appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. What is the best age to buy a home?
entry.summary: On average, people in 18 countries say the ideal age to buy a first home is just before 30. The post 3. What is the best age to buy a home? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. What is the best age to retire?
entry.summary: On average, people in 18 countries say the ideal age to retire is around 58 years old. The age adults can start receiving retirement benefits varies by country. The post 4. What is the best age to retire? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. What is the best age to have a first child?
entry.summary: On average, people in 18 countries say the ideal age to have a child is around 26 years old. Women in the countries polled generally give birth a bit later in life. The post 2. What is the best age to have a first child? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. What is the best age to get married?
entry.summary: On average, people in 18 countries say the ideal age to get married is around 26 years old. In general, people in the countries polled do marry in their 20s. The post 1. What is the best age to get married? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Overlanding in Alaska, where glaciers meet bear country
entry.summary:
Alaska offers an abundance of different terrains to explore. Travelling in Alaska â€” the USâ€™s final frontier â€” can feel like jumping through a wormhole. Time here is marked not by the clock, but by the changing of the seasons. Though cruising is a popular way to explore, travelling by land allows more exposure to the wild landscapes of south-central Alaska, from the glaciers of Prince William Sound to a park where travellers can walk with bears.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). After hiking in Chugach State Park, just east of Anchorage, where trails weave between hemlock and spruce trees, itâ€™s onwards to Lake Clark National Park. Reached via a small â€˜tundra tyreâ€™ plane, itâ€™s a rare place where travellers can get relatively close to grizzlies in the wild, accompanied by bear biologists. This is possible thanks to the neutral relationship the parkâ€™s lodges have nurtured with the coastal brown bears. You might find them among pink fireweed plants, which bloom white before wilting to brown by winter. At 27 miles long, the Matanuska Glacier is the largest in the US accessible by road. It takes less than two hours to get here from Anchorage along the scenic Glenn Highway, and many who visit Alaska by land make a detour to this rippling sea of ice on the way from Anchorage to Denali National Park. Travellers passing through the Matanuska Valley can drive right up to the base of the glacier and walk on it with a guide or try ice climbing. Tours provide equipment such as helmets and crampons, and give a unique, up-close perspective on the glacierâ€™s eerie fissures, luminous blue caves and walls of ice that groan and creak. Published in the USA guide, available with the Jan/Feb 2025 issue of National Geographic Traveller (UK). To subscribe toÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK) magazine click here. (Available in select countries only).

entry.title: How Thailand became a world leader in edible insects
entry.summary:
Jars of edible insects are arranged to showcase their diversity in the kitchen of Akkee, a Michelin-starred restaurant in the outskirts of Bangkok that utilizes a variety of seasonal insects in their dishes. Gourmet dishes, cricket burgers, buttery bamboo caterpillarsâ€”Thai edible insect business is booming. Can it inspire the world?
Growing up in Thailandâ€™s northeastern Isan region, Suwimon Chantajohn learned from her grandfather which insects were best to eat. Captivated by his stories of surviving on bugs during his military service in World War II, she spent her childhood scouring the dry fields for crickets, bamboo worms, and scarab beetles hiding in the grass, under bark, or beneath cow dung.
As an adult, she wanted to start her own business and traveled the world. Whileâ€¦

entry.title: Celebrate 850 years of Glasgowâ€”here's what to see and do
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Glasgow is famously friendly â€” and famously rainy, with some 170 drizzly days each year. But the grey weather comes with an upside: this city pours its heart and soul into its cultural pursuits. After all, when thereâ€™s little chance of lolling around in the sun, you may as well start an art movement, a band or a restaurant.
The household names to have come out of Glasgow are legion â€” from designer-architect Charles Rennie Mackintosh, football manager Alex Ferguson and singer Lulu to actor Peter Capaldi and comedian Frankie Boyle â€” and youâ€™ll find some of the UKâ€™s best theatres, music venues and museums here.
Walking around the city centre, Glasgowâ€™s prosperous past is evident: its grand Victorian banking hallsâ€¦

entry.title: What toll does spaceflight take on astronauts?
entry.summary:
On September 15, 2021, a SpaceX Dragon capsule carried the Inspiration4 crew into space via a Falcon 9 rocket. During their three-day mission, spacecraft reached an altitude of 575 kilometers (km) above Earthâ€™s surface, farther in space than the orbit of the International Space Station, which ranges from 370km to 460km. A new database aims to pave the way for a better understanding of space health and medicine as more civilian missions launch.
Over the past five decades, under 700 humans have flown in space. Nearly every one of those humans were professionally trained astronauts and in similar peak physical condition. And most of those astronauts were men. But in 2021, the first space mission with four civilian astronautsâ€”meaning, not government agency astronautsâ€”flew. It opened a â€¦

entry.title: This may be Europeâ€™s best-kept secret for family vacations
entry.summary:
With calm waves and sandy shores, it's easy to spend a day on the beach in the Algarve. With its pristine beaches, charming fishing villages, vineyards, and medieval castles, the Algarve region of Portugal offers a wide range of adventures.
  When you hear someone say they are planning a family trip to Portugal, Lisbon is often the destination that comes to mind. And while Portugal's capital is worth the hype, you'd miss out on Europe's best-kept secret for family vacations, the Algarve. Located less than three hours south of Lisbon, the Algarve (from Arabicâ€™s al-garbh for "the westâ€) is the southernmost region of Portugal. Renowned for its golden cliffs, silky sand beaches, picturesque towns, and delectable cuisine, it provides the perfect blend of adventure, relaxatiâ€¦

entry.title: These fish can spot their favorite divers
entry.summary:
Several times during almost 20 years of conducting research on fish in the wild, Alex Jordan, a researcher who leads the Behavioural Evolution Lab at the Max Planck Institute of Animal Behavior, had the feeling that the fish he was studying were learning to recognize and follow him or his colleagues.
â€œThere were a lot of times when it was obviousÂ to us that fish were recognizing us,â€ he recalls.
But while scientists seemed to intuitively suspect this, no studies looked at this phenomenon in the wild.
â€œ[Fish] are a lot more complicated than we give them credit for,â€ says Cait Newport, a marine biologist at Oxford University who wasnâ€™t involved in the new research.
To test their hunch, Jordan and his colleagues traveled to the French Mediterranean island of Corsica, whereâ€¦

entry.title: Astronauts getting stuck in space is more common than you think
entry.summary:
NASA astronauts (clockwise from bottom) Matthew Dominick, Jeanette Epps, Sunita Williams, Mike Barratt, Tracy Dyson, and Barry Wilmore, pose for a team portrait on the International Space Station on July 11. Williams and Wilmore were supposed to spend roughly eight days in space, after arriving on the Boeing Starliner's first flight in June. As Sunita Williams and Barry Wilmore finally return home, here's where they fit in a long list of astronauts who got to spend more time on the ISS than expected.
Thanks to technical problems with their Boeing Starliner spacecraft, Sunita Williams and Barry Wilmore have spent a lot more time on the International Space Station than originally planned. After around nine months in space, they are returning to Earth aboard a SpaceX capsule with two â€¦

entry.title: We found the perfect swim trunks for men
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
The best swim trucks blend quick-drying materials, comfort, and style. For some, that means one that doesnâ€™t restrict movement. â€œI like a shorter swim trunkâ€”nothing down to my knees. It should be lightweight, not restrictive, and not create drag while swimming,â€ says Peyton Bergmann, a teacher and avid outdoorsman based in Ypsilanti, Michigan. â€œI also want optionsâ€”something with a cool design, not just a plain color.â€Â
Others prefer trunks that traâ€¦

entry.title: The ultimate guide to Salzburg for â€˜The Sound Of Musicâ€™ superfans
entry.summary: The classic movie The Sound of Music celebrates its 60th anniversary in 2025, but beyond its milestone celebrations this year, there are several experiences inspired by the famous flick that fans should not miss out on when visiting Salzburg, Austria. From the hills of the opening scene to the mountain over which they escape, hereâ€™s how to follow in the footsteps of the von Trapp family in real life. The hills are still alive withÂ The Sound of Music. Sixty years after this family feel-good classic movie premiered, fans still travel toÂ SalzburgÂ to see where the story of the singing Trapp family began. Whether filmed on location or on elaborate Hollywood sets, the original, real-life locations havenâ€™t changed.Â Â  Travelers can relive the nostalgia of the famous movie and tâ€¦

entry.title: Explore 7 of the best pilgrimages in the UK
entry.summary:
The Mourne mountains offer a fantastic pitstop on the St Patrick's Way in Northern Ireland. While traditional religious practices may be on the decline, pilgrimages â€” meditative, multi-day hikes â€” are experiencing a resurgence. Explore the routes that are offering new, mindful journeys in our increasingly secular world.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Back in the day, a pilgrimage meant a journey to a sacred place as an act of religious devotion. Today, for increasing numbers of pilgrims, itâ€™s a journey made with purpose and a touch of spirituality â€” though not necessarily driven by faith. The UK has become one of the worldâ€™s most secular countries; the last census saw the percentage of Christians in England and Wales drop from 59% to 46%. Anâ€¦

entry.title: Snowboarder Jeremy Jones fights to keep our winters cold
entry.summary:
Jeremy Jones photographed by Jonas Fredwall Karlsson in Olympic Valley, California Along with his outdoor-sports peers, the backcountry legend is leading an unlikely contingent of climate activists on a mission to keep winter powder fresh and abundant.
A pioneer of big-mountain snowboarding, Jeremy Jones watched as helicopters made remote backcountry runs suddenly reachable, enabling access to lines that had once been unfathomably remote. â€œWe would get dropped in the mountains and link up these runs where you hike and ride and hike and ride,â€ he says. â€œI was like, Oh my God, this is where I need to be.â€ But he had misgivings about the means of ascent. â€œI knew, when I got in a helicopter, I was taking up resources,â€ he says. He began hiking up mountains instead and found the experieâ€¦

entry.title: Mountaineer Carla PÃ©rez wants to empower everyone
entry.summary:
Carla PÃ©rez photographed by Nanna Heitmann in Kyanjin Gompa, Nepal Climbing, she says, allows for an â€œexploration of your body, of your limits, of the possibilities that you have.â€ Sheâ€™s working to ensure people with disabilities have the chance to experience it.
Carla PÃ©rez can feel the difference when she crosses the invisible line that marks 8,300 meters, or roughly 27,000 feet, above sea level. â€œBefore that wall, you still have a lot of control over what you think and what you do,â€ she says. â€œItâ€™s, like, normalâ€”almost normal.â€â€¯But when PÃ©rez, 42, climbs higher, things change. â€œYou start to lose your control of your mind. You cannot talk very wellâ€”itâ€™s like you are drunk,â€ she explains. Her body responds sluggishly to her commands: Thoughts and movements materialize on an agonizâ€¦

entry.title: How Shu Yang finds inspiration for game-changing new ideas
entry.summary:
For Shu Yang, ideas are everywhere. Sometimes nature provokes inspiration. Other times, a problem causes Yang to see a solution that already exists in the natural world. While trying to create a â€œbuilding envelopeâ€ that could reflect sunlight and collect water to passively heat and cool buildings, she looked to tornado vortices for a new structure for perforated window covers. The dry, grooved skin of the African elephant helped her envision a new kind of stucco that would keep temperatures down in regions experiencing life-threatening heat waves. Yang also developed an adhesive thatâ€™s strong enough to hold shelving on walls yet porous enough to be removed if the glue is remoistened. Snail secretion gave her a model to perfect the design.Â
Yang, a chemical and biomolecular engineer atâ€¦

entry.title: Pattie Gonia wants to make the outdoors more welcoming
entry.summary:
Pattie Gonia photographed by Djeneba Aduayom near Three Fingered Jack peak in Oregon The nature-loving drag queen and environmentalist has big plans for making LGBTQ people feel more comfortable in the outdoors community.
The outdoors can sometimes feel hostile for the queer community. Thatâ€™s a conclusion Wyn Wiley reached as a kid at a summer camp run by the Boy Scouts. â€œI was indoctrinated into this militaristic, masculine outdoor system of â€˜You have to be strong to survive,â€™â€ Wiley recalls.
Today that kid raised under a stifling vision of the outdoors leads a movement built on a very different storyâ€”and does so in heels. After going viral in 2018 for hiking in six-inch-heeled boots, the worldâ€™s premier â€œbackpacking queenâ€ was born: Pattie Gonia, an activist in drag whoâ€™s tâ€¦

entry.title: Arlo Parks is ready to amplify other peoples' stories
entry.summary:
Arlo Parks photographed by Micaiah Carter in Los Angeles In her songs, the London-born musician probes her intimate moments of her life. In her work as UNICEFâ€™s youngest U.K. ambassador, sheâ€™s trying to amplify other peopleâ€™s stories.
The London-born musician and poet Arlo Parks makes indie pop with the warmth and tenderness of folk. And since her 2021 debut album, Collapsed in Sunbeams, sheâ€™s become known for songs that are so strikingly candid and familiar that they can seem like diorama boxes filled with lifeâ€™s tiniest moments. â€œI just have my notebook for every record,â€ she says, â€œand Iâ€™m collecting fragments and phrases and nuggets from my life, and thatâ€™s where the music comes from.â€Â
Because her music is so possessed by interior life, it can naturally seem to yearn for â€¦

entry.title: Tayshan Hayden-Smith helps rebuild placesâ€”with plants
entry.summary:
Tayshan Hayden-Smith photographed by Robin Hammond in the North Kensington neighborhood of London The former pro soccer player has returned home to London with a plan to rejuvenate the cityâ€™s neighborhoodsâ€”and empower its young peopleâ€”with urban gardening.
When Tayshan Hayden-Smith was growing up with his three siblings in London public housing, he dreamed of playing for Arsenal, the famous football club, and the familyâ€™s small garden became his pitch. He honed his skills dribbling between his motherâ€™s rosebushes and lavender plants, his shots careening off her avocado tree. â€œIt was like the garden versus football,â€ he recalls. For a time, in the backyard and in his heart, football reigned supreme, and by the time he was 20, he was playing professionally in Austria.â€¯Â
Then, onâ€¦

entry.title: Meet the builders making schools from plastic waste
entry.summary:
Isabel Cristina GÃ¡mez and Oscar AndrÃ©s MÃ©ndez photographed by Robin Hammond in BogotÃ¡, Colombia Isabel Cristina GÃ¡mez and Oscar AndrÃ©s MÃ©ndez have developed a novel system that repurposes shampoo bottles and food packaging into a modular system far cheaper than traditional construction.
The idea was simple yet profound. What if you could use the plastic waste littering your home country to help solve its housing crisis? For architect Oscar AndrÃ©s MÃ©ndez and his business partner, electronics engineer Isabel Cristina GÃ¡mez, that inspiration led to an invention that embodies their core values.Â Â
Their Colombia-based company, Conceptos PlÃ¡sticos, transforms plastic, including bags, snack-food containers, and shampoo bottles, into a modular building system of bricks and columns.â€¯Thâ€¦

entry.title: Maya Gabeira surfs big wavesâ€”and helps to rid them of plastic
entry.summary:
Maya Gabeira photographed by Matthieu Paley in NazarÃ©, Portugal As a big-wave surfer, the Brazilian adrenaline junkie set records at the highest surf break on Earth. Sheâ€™s still committed to the oceanâ€”now, though, sheâ€™s dedicating herself to helping keep it clean for future generations.
For much of the year, the ocean at NazareÌ, a fishing village on Portugalâ€™s coast, is placid. But in the winter, certain storms funnel swells through an underwater canyon, transforming the waves into moving mountains of water so colossal they have been described as the Everest of the ocean.
Big-wave surfers have made pilgrimages to the town since 2011, when a video of Garrett McNamara barreling down a 78-foot wave established it as having one of the planetâ€™s biggest breaks. Over much of the pasâ€¦

entry.title: Gabriela Hearst is pushing the edge in sustainable fashion
entry.summary:
Gabriela Hearst photographed by Joyce Ng in Hearstâ€™s atelier in New York City Long before it became trendy in fashion circles, environmentalism was the guiding ethos in the designerâ€™s work. â€œWhat am I going to do, another collection based on a â€™70s icon?â€
A visitor to the Manhattan office of Gabriela Hearst doesnâ€™t need to peruse the impeccably well-made clothes to spot proof of the fashion designerâ€™s impact. â€œThose recycled cardboard hangers you see?â€ Hearst says, pointing. â€œWe were one of the first to develop them.â€ Her abhorrence of the plastic kind owes to its frequent fate: the landfill.Â
Today the 48-year-old designerâ€”who grew up on a ranch in Uruguay and launched her eponymous brand a decade agoâ€”is a prestige player in the world of fashion and embodies the quiet luxury â€¦

entry.title: Lucie Basch wants to stop uneaten food from going to waste
entry.summary:
Lucie Basch photographed by Robin Hammond in Paris At 24, she rallied restaurants to join her app and pledge to distribute uneaten food. The app didnâ€™t exist yet. Now Too Good to Go has more than 100 million users.
When she was 24 years old, Lucie Basch left a promising career at NestlÃ© determined to build an app to fight food waste. She had zero coding knowledge, no marketing experience, and no funding. What she did have, however, was a simmering disdain for just how much good food winds up in the trashâ€”about 30 percent of global productionâ€”which creates as much as 10 percent of greenhouse gas emissions as it rots.Â
Food waste happens all along the supply chain, but another thing Basch did not have was specialized expertise in agriculture or manufacturing. So she focused on wâ€¦

entry.title: Why Yara Shahidi is speaking up for optimism
entry.summary: Yara Shahidi photographed by Micaiah Carter in Malibu, California The voice-of-a-generation star of Black-ish and Grown-ish is searching for bright spots in tricky times. â€œYoung people rise to the occasion time and time again.â€  â€œWhat does optimism mean to you right now?â€ Itâ€™s a question that Yara Shahidi, best known for her role as the Gen Z cool girl Zoey Johnson on the hit show Black-ish and its spin-off, Grown-ish (both produced by ABC, which shares a parent company with National Geographic), often asks at the beginning of her new podcast, The Optimist Project, which wrestles with how to live a more fulfilling life.â€¯Â  As suicide rates rise in the United States and the world seems awash in anxiety-inducing headlines, itâ€™s a question that has become ever mâ€¦

entry.title: BjÃ¶rk the artist is unconstrained. The activist is pragmatic.
entry.summary:
BjÃ¶rk always seems to inhabit an alternate universeâ€”a dreamlike space of the highest creative ambition, free from the constraints that govern mere mortals. Which makes it all the more jarring when she injects her work with a dose of cold reality. In January she released a concert film shot during her recent Cornucopia tour. The show featured signature BjÃ¶rk flourishes, including expansive arrangements of Icelandâ€™s HamrahlÃ­Ã° Choir; giant, psychedelic projections of fungi; and the flashing of an environmental manifesto making an explicit appeal to the most urgent issue of our time: â€œThe Paris climate accord is a modern utopia impossible to imagine, but overcoming our environmental challenges is the only way we can survive.â€Â
Over Zoom one day last winter, she explained what she was gettâ€¦

entry.title: The doctor who believes pig hearts could end our organ shortage
entry.summary:
Muhammad Mansoor Mohiuddin photographed by Jonas Fredwall Karlsson at the University of Maryland School of Medicine in Baltimore Surgeon Muhammad Mansoor Mohiuddin is a leader in the novel field of xenotransplantationâ€”transferring organs from one species to anotherâ€”in his case, from pigs to humans.
Sometimes tragedies can be breakthroughs. Or the beginnings of breakthroughs. Thatâ€™s what happened a few years ago when a University of Maryland Medical Center surgical team, led by Muhammad Mansoor Mohiuddin and Bartley Griffith, performed a revolutionary new procedure on a 57-year-old who had terminal heart failure. David Bennett, Sr., had been denied a traditional heart transplant due to a variety of health factors. Thousands of people each year face a similar reality, in part becauseâ€¦

entry.title: Adam McKay believes we need humor to stave off disaster
entry.summary: Adam McKay photographed by Sebastian Kim, August Image The Anchorman and Donâ€™t Look Up filmmaker thinks the best way to encourage climate awareness isnâ€™t with sober factâ€”itâ€™s with biting satire.  A few years back, when filmmaker Adam McKay released his movie Donâ€™tÂ Look Upâ€”an apocalyptic satire that uses a killer comet as a metaphor for climate changeâ€”he was searching for a new way to talk about disaster. â€œAs horrific as this all is,â€ McKay says about climate change, â€œitâ€™s important that we create a culture around dealing with this epic, literally geological catastrophe weâ€™re confronting with humor.â€â€¯â€¯Â  When he started promoting the film, he got to wondering: Could humor actually galvanize some kind of response to the climate crisis? So his team did a â€¦

entry.title: Climate change: Paris Agreement goals still within reach, says UN chief
entry.summary: The effects of human-driven climate change surged to alarming levels in 2024, with some consequences likely to be irreversible for centuries - if not millennia â€“ according to a new report from the World Meteorological Organization (WMO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Intolerableâ€™ suffering in Gaza amid deadly airstrikes, continued aid blockade
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Tuesday spoke of new â€œintolerableâ€ suffering for Gazans following the resumption of deadly Israeli airstrikes, underscoring three immediate needs: a renewed ceasefire, unimpeded humanitarian access and the unconditional release of hostages.

entry.title: Human Rights Council focuses on Iran, Syria, Venezuela
entry.summary: Top independent experts reported to the UNÂ Human Rights Council in Geneva on Tuesday, putting the records of Iran, Syria and Venezuela under the spotlight during the 47-member bodyâ€™s latest session.

entry.title: Cyprus talks show â€˜new atmosphereâ€™ between divided islandâ€™s leaders: Guterres
entry.summary: UN-led efforts to kick-start talks on the divided Mediterranean island of Cyprus have resulted in agreements on new trust-building measures.

entry.title: UN migration agency forced to restructure amid significant budget cuts
entry.summary: The International Organization for Migration (IOM) is undertaking â€œessential structural adjustmentsâ€ at its Geneva headquarters and globally, in response to a substantial 30 per cent reduction in donor support for 2025 â€“ including a significant decrease in projects funded by the United States.

entry.title: How Planespotter and Other Transportation Enthusiast Sites Can Unlock Investigations
entry.summary: At NICAR25, data reporters detailed how amateur transportation enthusiasts are a valuable, media-friendly, and underused source of critical tips and information for investigations.

entry.title: Hereâ€™s why white sneakers are actually pretty great travel shoes
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Shoes are the biggest puzzle when it comes to packing. Whatâ€™s versatile, wonâ€™t take up too much space or bring your luggage over the weight limit? If youâ€™re not checking in a bag, choosing wisely is even more essential. The answer: A white sneaker.
That may sound surprising, but we love packing white sneakers for trips, as long as theyâ€™re properly prepped and maintained. â€œItâ€™s a great staple,â€ says New-York based freelance fashion director Sam Chadâ€¦

entry.title: How to travel like a local in Japan
entry.summary:
Travel experts recommend a relaxing, stress-free stay at a traditional Japanese inn or ryokan when visiting Japan. Itâ€™s a not-to-be-missed experience and a local favorite.  From subtropical islands to chilled-out ski resorts, there are so many places in Japan that don't suffer from the overtourism that's challenging more popular areas.
Japan is a deservedly popular destination, but travelers often wind up seeing the same sights and miss out on the far-flung, quieter, or less obvious corners of the country. To see a softer side of Japan, we asked locals, from writers to motorcycle enthusiasts, nonprofit workers to photographers, to share something about the places they love best.Â Travelers with only a day to spare should consider visiting Mount Takaoâ€”the most prominentâ€¦

entry.title: Everything you should know before visiting Japan
The 31 best Greek islands to visit in 2025
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
From the gastronomic isles of the Cyclades to the enigmatic ruins of the Dodecanese, each of the six main Greek island groups has its own distinct character. Yet, look closely and youâ€™ll find that more unites than sets them apart: there are secluded towns loved by local gourmands, hidden coves brimming with mythical associations and, above all, a natural splendour thatâ€™s captured the minds of artists and adventurers through the ages. Here are the best Greek islands to visit.
According to Greek mythology, it was Poseidon who seized a chunk of Kos and hurled it on top of a fiery Titan called Polyvotis â€” creating the volcanic island of Nisyros, with its enormous, sulphurous caldera. The volcano is active, but traveâ€¦

entry.title: How waves of immigration have created culinary magic in Tampa
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As I wander past the New Orleans-style iron verandahs, cigar shops and organic ice cream parlours on Tampaâ€™s palm-tree-lined 7th Avenue, I realise Iâ€™m being followed by a rooster. Like me, he seems to be heading to The Columbia â€” Floridaâ€™s oldest Spanish restaurant.
Itâ€™s a balmy November afternoon, and elderly gents and young people are shooting the breeze while smoking cigars in armchairs on the pavement, but nobody seems phased by my feathered friend. Here in Tampaâ€™s Ybor City neighbourhood, the rooster is king.
An official edict states the chickens must be allowed to roam free in honour of the areaâ€™s original Cuban immigrants, who raised the birds. Along with settlers from Spain, Italy, Germany, Switzerlandâ€¦

entry.title: Top 10 things to do in Japan
entry.summary:
Travelers should visit Senso-ji temple, Tokyoâ€™s oldest-established temple located in the cityâ€™s Asakusa neighborhood. It's just one of 10 things first-time visitors should do when exploring Japan. In a nation as culturally rich as Japan, it can be hard to know how to spend your time there. Here are ten of our favorite things to do.
Japan is an alluring destination because of its many juxtapositions. Neon skyscrapers tower over Shinto shrines, and salarymen ride the train next to Harajuku girls. The Land of the Rising Sun also has diverse climates and cultural attractions to please every style of traveler. Adventurers can ski Nisekoâ€™s slopes or hike Mount Fuji, while food lovers can eat their fill of street snacks in Osaka. Those seeking a more â€œZenâ€ vacation can relax in outdoor hâ€¦

entry.title: Why the equinox ushers in the arrival of spring
entry.summary:
Every six months, once in March and again in September, an equinox splits Earthâ€™s day almost in half, giving us about 12 hours of daylight and 12 of night.
On March 20, 2025, the vernal equinox will signal the coming of spring for the Northern Hemisphere. Then, in September, nature will once again bring us the autumnalÂ equinox, the time of year that ushers in fall in the North. Those dates are swapped for the vernal and autumnal equinoxes in the Southern Hemisphere.
(Here's why each season begins twice.) undefinedWhat are equinoxes? What causes these astronomical events? Find out how they influence the seasons and hours of daylight on each planet. Our planet normally orbits the sun on an axis thatâ€™s tilted 23.5 degrees, meaning that the hemispheres trade off getting â€¦

entry.title: Joint UN meeting tackles small arms control to foster sustainable development
entry.summary: On Monday, during a meeting of the General Assembly and the Economic and Social Council, UN officials and disarmament experts emphasized the urgent need to tackle the widespread issue of small arms and light weapons. They warned that the stakes are higher than ever in a world increasingly plagued by conflict and crisis.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: LIVE NOW: Security Council meets on Gaza crisis, UN calls for urgent renewal of ceasefire and hostage releases
entry.summary: The UN Security Council is meeting in New York to discuss the Middle East crisis exactly two months since the start of the fragile Gaza ceasefire and hostages deal came into effect. That has been shattered by deadly Israeli airstrikes overnight, following a two-week aid blockade which has strained critical supplies. Well over 400 Palestinians have been killed and hundreds more injured, according to local authorities. We'll have reaction from across the UN and agencies on the ground. UN News app users follow live here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: US strikes on Yemen, Gaza aid update, debt burden weighs on developing world
entry.summary: The UN on Monday expressed concern over the continued threat posed to shipping in the Red Sea by Houthi attacks from their bases in Yemen as well as recent airstrikes by the United States which have left over 50 reportedly dead.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Funding shortages risk undermining a â€˜watershed momentâ€™ for Syria
entry.summary: Fourteen years of war have left Syriaâ€™s people in desperate need â€“ but international support is dwindling, UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres warned on Monday, calling for urgent investment in the countryâ€™s recovery.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: FAO warns of â€˜unprecedentedâ€™ avian flu spread, in call for global action
entry.summary: The rapid spread of the highly infectious avian flu virus H5N1 has reached an â€œunprecedentedâ€ scale, wiping out hundreds of millions of birds worldwide and increasingly spilling over into mammals, the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) warned on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Afghanistan: Security Council renews UN mission as WHO warns of health catastrophe
entry.summary: The Security Council on Monday extended the mandate of the UN Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA) for another year, as UN agencies reported sharp declines in resources for lifesaving aid.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: Relative of Assad regimeâ€™s disappeared speaks of anguish in search for truth and justice
entry.summary: A relative of two Syrians tortured and murdered by the Assad regime has spoken of the anguish caused by their enforced disappearance during the countryâ€™s civil war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories
